loans.name: Mercedes

texts.en:
Mercedes D. C. main source of income comes from raising pigs for breeding. She is 46 years old, widowed and has four school-age children. They are from the village of Brgy. Paniki, Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya. Mercedes has been in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 8,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month.

In 2006, Mercedes joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Mercedes has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from ASKI which was used to purchase breeding livestock. She is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This will be her tenth loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Hilda

texts.en: Hilda A.'s main source of income comes from raising pigs for fattening and sale. She is 39 years old, married and has two school-age children. They are from the village of Alinam, Cauayan City, Isabela. Hilda has been in her business for over two years and earns approximately 3,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2009, Hilda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Hilda is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This will be her third loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Aurora

texts.es:
La Sra. Aurora G. tiene 35 años, esta casada con el Sr. Jose Vargas, juntos tienen 2 hijos, los cuales acuden a la escuela cerca de su domicilio. 

La Sra. Aurora vende comida en su mismo domicilio, prepara platos tipicos como majadito y otros platos como charque, chicharron de chanco. El Sr. Jose es constructor Albañil, se dedican a estas actividades desde hace ya mucho  tiempo, por lo cual tienen los ingresos necesarios para la educacion de sus hijos y gastos familiares en general.

Requieren del Préstamo para finalizar la construcción de su vivienda y asi darles mejor condicion de vida a sus hijos.
texts.en:
Mrs. Aurora G., 35, is married to Mr. José Vargas. They have two children who go to a school near their home. Aurora sells home-made food. She prepares typical regional dishes like majadito (shredded, dried meat with tomatoes and other ingredients; sometimes served with a fried egg on top) and others like charque (salted beef), chicharrón (fried pork rinds). José works in construction as a bricklayer. They have been in these occupations for a long time now so they earn sufficient income to pay for their children’s education and general family expenses. They need the loan to finish building their house so that they can thus provide better living conditions for their children.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For home construction.

loans.name: Gilver Sandalio

texts.es:
El Sr. Gilver J. tiene 32 años, esta casado con la Sra. Paola Villegas hace 3 años, tienen un hijo de 2 años. Viven en la casa de su madre.

El Sr. Gilver es pintor desde hace 12 años, tiene mucha experiencia como pintor por lo que genera ingresos para el cuidado de su hijo y de su esposa.

Requiere del préstamo para poder comprar un vehiculo, debido que para su trabajo necesitara mucho y se convertira en su herramienta de trabajo para poder trasladar a sus ayudantes y sus otras herramientas de trabajo, ayudara mucho para dar un mejor servicio de pintado.
texts.en:
Mr. Gilver Jiménez, 32, has been married to Mrs. Paola Villegas for the last 3 years. They have a two-year-old son. They live in his mother’s house. He has been a painter for the last 12 years and has a lot of experience in this line of work. He earns income sufficient to care for his son and wife. He needs the loan to buy a vehicle because he needs one for his work. It will become a work tool in that he can use it to transport his helpers and other work tools. It will be of great help for him to provide better painting services.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Tu purchase a vehicle for work.

loans.name: Johana Del Carmen

texts.es: Johana del Carmen M. F. tiene un pequeño y modesto puesto de venta de pollo el cual inicio hace un año y donde trabaja en conjunto con sus hijos mayores los cuales atienden el negocio. Esta señora de 35 años tiene cinco hijos de 16, 15, 10 y 6 años  y el menor de tan solo 6 meses y su meta principal aumentar su negocio con mayor cantidad de productos e invertir en otros rubros hasta tener una distribuidora.
texts.en:
Johana del Carmen M. F. has a small, modest chicken sales stand that she opened a year ago. She works there with her two oldest sons. She is 35 years old and has five children who are 16, 15, 10 and 6 years of age; the baby is only 6 month old. Her main goal is to enlarge her business with larger amounts of products and to invest in other products until becoming a major distributor.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy larger amounts of chicken.

loans.name: Angela

texts.es:
Doña Ángela de 61 años de edad, es una madre esforzada, y de pocos recursos económicos, vive con su familia, siete hijos, su esposo trabaja como técnico de pista.
Desde joven trabaja, como conserje pues es el medio para lograr obtener ingresos para cubrir los gastos.
Su casa aun no ha logrado hacer de concreto, es de madera y zinc, y su objetivo es levantar una pared de concreto logrando así un mejor techo
El cual lo hará mediante el financiamiento, que el medio viable a plazos.
Comprara materiales de construcción como: doscientos bloques, dos quintales de hierro, arena, cemento para iniciar la obra.
Gracias al apoyo de su familia y la institución podrá comenzar a mejorar su casa, lo que es de necesidad.
texts.en:
Ángela is 61 years old, is a mother who works very hard, and she has few economic resources. She lives with her family, seven children and a husband who works as a road technician. She has worked as a janitor since she was young. It is her means of getting income to cover the expenses. She still has not managed to make her house in concrete. It is made of wood and zinc sheeting. Her objective is to raise a concrete wall, which will make a better roof. She will do this through the loan, which is viable with installments. She will buy construction materials like 200 blocks, 2 “quintales” (weight measure equivalent to 46 kilos) of iron, sand, and cement to start the work. Thanks to support from her family and the institution she will be able to start improving her house, which is a necessity.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy construction materials like blocks, iron, sand, and cement cemento, to raise a concrete wall and improve her house

loans.name: Felix Armando

texts.es:
Don Félix es padre de familia de cuatro hijos, tienen la edad de 42 años, comerciante de muebles y electrodomésticos  el cual estos productos los vende por encargo.
Tiene nueve años que comenzó con sus ventas, y ha logrado tener sus 
 Clientes, anteriormente se dedicaba a la venta de madera, pero trabaja sin el permiso, lo que se perjudico ya que tubo problemas legales.
Es por eso da un jiro a su negocio y comienza a comprar ya hecho los muebles el cual da a un mejor precio.
También tiene unas tierras que su papa heredo, el cual en tiempo libres trabaja en ella ya que siembra tomate, chiltoma, logrando así tener otros ingresos.
Para incrementar sus ventas en productos, y al no tener el suficiente capital para comprar.
Toma la iniciativa del financiamiento que otorga al pequeño comerciante para mejorar la expectativa e incremento del negocio.
texts.en:
Félix is the father of four children. He is 42 years old and is a furniture and home appliance merchant. He sells his items based on prior orders. He started his business 9 years ago and has managed to secure regular customers. He used to sell lumber but he was doing so without proper permits and this was harmful to him in that he had legal problems as a result. Therefore, he changed jobs and started to buy ready-made furniture which he then resells at good prices. He also owns some farmland his father left him. In his spare time he works the fields planting tomatoes and peppers thereby earning additional income. In order to increase his products sales and not having enough capital to buy them, he took the initiative to request financing available to small businesses to improve his expectations and increase his business.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: He will buy furniture like armoires, closets and tables, among others, at good prices from a furniture store then reselling to his customers at accessible prices.

loans.name: Maria Isabel

texts.es:
Maria Isabel es una mujer comerciante dedicada al trabajo, durantes años lleva vendiendo tortillas, cosa de horno también vende carne de cerdo, logrando tener mejor ingreso, ya que cuentan con pocos recursos económicos, y la canasta básica esta cara.
Su esposo es jardinero y junto han hecho su pequeña casa de bloques y madera, su cocina aun no tiene solo un techo donde palmea sus ricas tortillas, que espera en un futuro poder construir para una mejor higiene.
Con este préstamo comprara materia prima para seguir aumentando la producción en venta de tortilla y cosa de horno. Comprara. Maíz, azúcar, dulce, cal, leña, manteca  logrando así su objetivo.
texts.en:
Maria Isabel is a business woman dedicated to working. She has been selling tortillas, baked goods and pork for several years which has allowed her to have a better income since she has few economic resources and her basic needs are expensive. Her husband is a gardener and together they have built their small home of blocks and wood. Her kitchen, where she makes her delicious tortillas, does not yet have a roof. She hopes to be able to build a roof in the future for better hygiene. With this loan she will buy supplies so that she can increase her production and sale of tortillas and baked goods. She will buy corn, sugar, sweets, lime, wood and lard to achieve her goal.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Manzo, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase corn, sugar, sweets, lime, wood and lard to increase her production and sale of tortillas and baked goods.

loans.name: Erika Del Rosario

texts.es:
Erika es una joven comerciante de 27 años de edad, se dedica a la venta de ropa y cosméticos, inicio hace cinco años con préstamos.
Es madre de dos hijos, y su esposo trabaja como asistente en un banco.
Sus planes es comprar  dos vitrinas para poder exhibir sus productos y lograr la atracción del cliente.
Los productos que vende,  los compra en el mercado Oriental donde lo halla  a buen precio, y otros de Avon que gustan mucho al cliente y que trae por encargo. Vende al contado y al crédito.
Lo que quiere es invertir es en cosmético y perfumes, ropa de varón ya que tiene poco inventario y desea invertir logrando aumentar sus ganancias que es con la que ayuda a su pequeña familia. Lo que no ha logrado hasta el momento es su nivel alta en ventas, es por eso opta al financiamiento para dar otro jiro a su negocio.
texts.en:
Erika is a young, 27 year old merchant. She sells clothes and cosmetics. She started five years ago with loans. She has two children, and her husband works in a bank as an assistant. Her plan is to buy two display cases to be able to show her products and attract customers. She buys her products in the Oriental Market, where she finds good prices. She also gets Avon by order, which her customers like a lot. She sells for cash and credit. What she wants to do is invest more in cosmetics, perfume, and men’s clothes. She has a small inventory, and she wishes to invest in order to increase her earnings. She helps her small family with her earnings. Up until now she has not managed to have a high level of sales. That is why she opted for a loan to give her business another go round.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy cosmetics, perfume, and men’s clothes to increase sales

loans.name: Joel Moisés

texts.es:
El  Sr. Joel Moisés R. M. trabaja como ayudante de bodega en el centro de insumos para la salud. Es padre  de familia  de dos hijos y uno de ellos encuentra en edad escolar.
El préstamo solicitado es para la compra de materiales de construcción como: verjas, y ventanas para su casa de habitación.
Don Joel ha trabajado dos créditos con la institución y estos han sido para el mejoramiento de su vivienda.
texts.en:
Mr. Joel Moisés R. M. works as a storeroom assistant at the health supplies center. He is the father of two children; one of the children is of school age. The requested loan is for purchasing construction materials like window grilles and windows for his home. Don Joel has had two loans with this institution, and they have both been for home improvement.

Translated from Spanish by Danielle Maxson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Construction materials for home

loans.name: Paula Lorgia

texts.es: La  Sra. Paula Lorgia P. P.    ella es comerciante se dedica al negocio  de abarrotes ella tiene veinte y cuatros  años de dedicarse a ese negocio, Ha tenido  trece créditos con CEPRODEL y todos los ha realizado para ampliar y mejorar su negocio  en mercadería
texts.en:
Paula is a merchant who sells groceries. She has dedicated herself to her business for 24 years. Paula has had 13 loans with CEPRODEL and all were used to expand and improve her merchandising business.

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Compra de granos basicos

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is a member of Mwireri Nyakahura Group which is being funded by Juhudi Kilimo. She is a farmer from the town of Murang'a in Central Kenya. She has been practicing mixed farming for the last 30 years and has employed one permanent employee and four casual laborers. Her main product is french beans which she sells locally. She also operates a green grocery in the same area but faces the challenge of a poor market for her product.

Margaret has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo for 53,000 Kenyan shillings to purchase and insure a dairy cow. She says that the family's income will increase through the sale of milk. She would like to venture into dairy farming and increase the quality of her dairy cows in future.

Margaret is 53 years old. She is married and has 9 children who are all adults.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy is 33 years old. She is a married mother of three children with ages ranging between 1 and 11. Two of her children attend school. 
Nancy has been practicing mixed farming for the last 10 years in the town of Kitale in Western Kenya. Her main products are milk and maize which she sells to Kenya Cooperative Creameries and National Cereals Board respectively. She also operates a small shop in her area.

Nancy has requested this loan of 40,000 Kenyan shillings through Juhudi Kilimo to construct a dairy unit and start a poultry project. She says that this loan will improve her dairy farming and increase her income. However, she faces the challenge of inadequate animal feed. In the future, she would like to improve her dairy farming and purchase a vehicle to help transport her produce to the market.

loans.use: To construct a dairy unit and start a poultry project

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en:
Veronica has been farming for the last 25 years on the outskirts of Kitale town in Western Kenya. Her farm produces maize, beans and milk, which she sells locally. She also operates a small restaurant in her area. Her biggest challenges have been poultry diseases and fluctuation in the market price of her products.

Veronica has requested this loan of 50,000 Kenyan shillings from Juhudi Kilimo to start a poultry project. She hopes that the extra income from this loan will enable her to improve the standard of living of her family.

Veronica is 47 years old. She is married and has been blessed with seven children between the ages of 14 and 28. Four of the children are currently attending school. She hopes that in five years time, she will not only be keeping the indigenous birds, but also keeping layers and broilers.

loans.use: To start a poultry project

loans.name: Joan

texts.en:
Joan is 45 years old. She is married and has four children between the ages of 9 and 27. Two of her children are attending school. 

Joan has been farming on the outskirts of Kitale town in Western Kenya for the last 20 years. Her main products are milk and maize, which she sells to Kenya Cooperative Creameries and the National Cereals Board respectively. She also earns income from bricks that she sells at the local market.

Joan has requested this loan of 46,800 Kenyan shillings from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. She says that this loan will improve her dairy farming, since it will increase her milk production, and earn her more income. Her biggest challenge has been lack of enough animal feed but, with training, she has been able to improve her breed.

Joan would like to supply her milk to a milk chilling plant in her village and purchase a deep freezer that will help her store her milk in the future. She is grateful to Juhudi for empowering her economically.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Frida

texts.en:
Frida is a farmer from Kitale town in Western Kenya. She has been farming for the last four years and employs one farmhand. Her farm produces maize, beans, vegetables and milk, which she sells locally. She also earns income from her chemist's which she runs in the same area.

Frida recently completed her fourth loan from Juhudi Kilimo and has requested this loan of 80,000 Kenyan shillings to expand her poultry project and build a dairy unit. She says that this loan will help increase her sources of income and she will be in a position to look after the needs of her family.

Frida is 33 years old and married with four children between the ages of 3 and 13. Three of the children are currently attending school. In the future, she hopes to expand her poultry project and also to acquire a high breed dairy cow to increase her productivity.

loans.use: To expand her poultry project and build a dairy unit

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand his poultry project

loans.name: Mujeres Progresistas (Cuenca) Group

texts.es:
El banco comunal Mujeres Progresistas esta formado por 9 mujeres luchadoras, emprendedoras y sobre todo que ven  la vida con mucha alegría, buscan con su trabajo diario brindar un mejor futuro a sus hijos. Viven en la ciudad de Cuenca, esta es la tercera ciudad más importante del Ecuador, también cuenta con un centro histórico muy hermoso siendo el orgullo de sus habitantes.

La Señora Jenny T. vive por el sector de la Feria Libre, tiene 24 años, es divorciada y tiene una hija de 3 años de edad, vive en casa de sus padres pero de una manera independiente, el papá de su hija se ha hecho responsable de pasarle la pensión mensual alimenticia.
Nuestra socia se dedica a 2 actividades de trabajo la primera es la venta de animales domésticos como son perros, gatos, conejos etc., realiza sus ventas de lunes a domingo todos los días, se dedica a este trabajo hace 4 años, también estudio para estilista en una academia y  se dedica a esta actividad  hace 6 años. Es nuestra socia hace 3 años y una amiga que pertenece al banco comunal fue quien la invito y le está muy agradecida, su nuevo crédito lo va a invertir en la compra de más animales y así ir creciendo en su negocio. Su meta es  viajar a los Estados Unidos para estudiar y perfeccionarse como estilista.
 
La Señora María H. vive por el sector de San Joaquín en la ciudad de Cuenca, se dedica hace 2 años a la limpieza de oficinas los 5  días de la semana, no tiene horario fijo, ya que sale cuando termina su trabajo, también se dedica a la cría de cuyes a los mismos  que los vende cuando tiene alguna necesidad o los utiliza para su consumo.
Nuestra socia tiene 28 años, es casada y tiene 2 hijos de 7 y 3 años de edad, su primera hija está en una escuela de la ciudad, su esposo trabaja en una ferretería y con el trabajo conyugal han logrado construir su casa propia. Es el primer crédito que realiza en la fundación, fue invitada por una gran amiga quien la incentivado para que se beneficies de estos pequeños créditos, su crédito lo va  a invertir en la compra de cuyes para crecer en su negocio. Su meta es construir un galpón para pollos y así tener  más  ingresos.
texts.en:
The Mujeres Progresistas (Progressive Women) communal bank is made up of 9 tenacious, enterprising women who face life with good cheer and seek through their daily work to provide a better future for their children. They live in the city of Cuenca, Ecuador’s third most important. It has a very beautiful, historic city center that is the pride of its residents. Mrs. Jenny T. lives in the Feria Libre sector. She’s 24 years old, divorced and has a 3-year-old daughter. She lives in her parents’ house but independently. Her daughter’s father has taken on the responsibility of providing her with a monthly food allowance. She is involved in two work-related activities. The first is the sale of domestic animals like dogs, cats, rabbits, etc. She sells from Monday through Sunday every day. She has been in this line of work for 4 years. She also attended an academy to study cosmetology and has been a hair stylist for 6 years. She has collaborated with us for 3 years; a girl friend of hers who is a member of the communal bank invited her and she is very grateful to her for this. The new loan will be used to buy more animals so that her business can grow. Her goal is to travel to the United States to study and become a better stylist. Mrs. María H. lives in Cuenca’s San Joaquín sector. For the last two years she has cleaned offices five days a week. She does not have a set schedule because she gets off work when the work is completed. She also raises guinea pigs that she sells when she has to raise money and also uses them for family consumption. She is 28 years old, married and has two children who are 7 and 3 years of age. Her oldest daughter goes to a local school. Her husband works in a hardware store and their effort as a couple has resulted in their being able to build their own house. This is her first loan with the foundation. She was invited by a girl friend who motivated her to avail herself of these small loans. She will use the loan to buy guinea pigs so that her business will grow. Her goal is to build a shed for chickens thus producing additional income.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy rabbits, guinea pigs, dogs, cats.

loans.name: Gladis Edid

texts.es:
La Señora Gladis Edid C. es socia del banco comunal Primero de Enero, vive en la comunidad Primero de Enero que pertenece a la parroquia del Valle, es de clima frió, su gente se dedica a la agricultura y ganadería, tiene como atractivo la hermosa laguna de Cochabamba (llena de totora).
 
La Señora Gladis Edid tiene 25 años, es madre soltera y tiene 2 hijos de 7 y 1 año de edad, su primer hijo estudia en una escuelita de la ciudad, recibe el apoyo del padre de sus hijos y vive en su casa propia la misma que la ha construido con su esfuerzo.
 
Nuestra socia se dedica a la venta de ropa surtida de adulto, la misma que la vende recorriendo la ciudad, realiza esta actividad hace 3 años sin tener un horario fijo de trabajo. Es su primer crédito que realiza en la fundación y le ha invitado una amiga a formar parte de este hermoso banco comunal, su crédito lo va a invertir en la compra de ropa interior, su meta es llegar a tener un local comercial.
texts.en:
Our member sells assorted clothing for adults in an itinerant manner throughout the city. She’s been in this line of work for three years and does not have a fixed work schedule. This is the first loan she’s gotten from the foundation. A girl friend invited her to be part of this beautiful communal bank. She will use the funds to buy underwear. Her goal is to have a fixed locale someday.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy underwear.

loans.name: Mayra Alejandra

texts.es:
La Señora Mayra Alejandra C. es socia del banco comunal Primero de Enero, vive por el sector de Totoracocha, en la ciudad de Cuenca que es  la tercera ciudad más importante del Ecuador, su hermoso centro histórico fue nombrado  patrimonio cultural de la humanidad.

Nuestra socia tiene 24 años, es casada y tiene 2 hijos de 5 y 4 años de edad, su primer hijo este año ingresa al jardín de infantes, su esposo es chofer y presta sus servicios en un taxi, no tienen casa propia por lo que viven arrendando.

Nuestra socia se dedica a la venta de todo tipo de ropa, labora 4 días a la semana y lleva en esta actividad un año, vende recorriendo la ciudad. Se encuentra en su primer ciclo y fue invitada por una amiga de la comunidad a formar parte de este gran grupo de mujeres luchadoras y emprendedoras, su crédito lo va a invertir en la compra de más mercadería.

Su meta es llegar a tener su casa propia.
texts.en:
Mrs. Mayra Alejandra C. is a member of the Primero de Enero (January 1st) communal bank. She lives in Cuenca’s Totoracocha sector. Cuenca is Ecuador’s third most important city. Its beautiful, historic city center was named Cultural Patrimony of Humanity. Mayra is 24 years old, married and has two children who are 5 and 4 years of age. Her oldest son will start kindergarten this year. Her husband is a taxi driver. They do not own their own home, they rent. She sells all kinds of clothes. She works four days a week and has been in this line of work for a year. She sells in an itinerant manner throughout the city. This is her first loan cycle and she was invited to become part of this great group of tenacious, enterprising women by a girl friend in the community. She will use the funds to buy more merchandise. Her goal is to own her own home someday.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy pants, blouses, t-shirts, dresses, etc.

loans.name: Anas Lucia

texts.es:
La Señora Ana Lucia S. es socia del banco comunal Primero de Enero, vive por el sector del Paraiso, en la ciudad de Cuenca que es reconocida por ser la tercera ciudad más importante del Ecuador,  su centro histórico fue nombrado como patrimonio cultural de la humanidad.

La Señora Ana Lucia se dedica a trabajar en una fábrica de embutidos en donde labora en turnos rotativos, empezó  este trabajo hace 9 meses y también se dedica a la venta de cosméticos en sus tiempos libres, lleva 2 años en esta labor.
 
Nuestra socia tiene 41 años, es divorciada hace 10 años y tiene 2 hijos de 18 y 17 años de edad, su primer hijo pasa en casa y ayuda a realizar los quehaceres  del hogar y su segunda hija estudia en un colegio de la ciudad de Cuenca, no tiene casa propia por lo que vive arrendando.

Es su primer crédito y fue invitada por su sobrina  a ingresar a este hermoso banco comunal, su crédito lo va a invertir en la compra de cosméticos para crecer más en su negocio. Su meta es llegar a tener un local propio para vender  ropa.
texts.en:
Mrs. Ana Lucia S. is a member of the Primero de Enero (January 1st) communal bank. She lives in Cuenca’s Paraíso sector. Cuenca is known for being Ecuador’s third most important city. Its historic city center was named Cultural Patrimony of Humanity. Ana Lucia works in a canning factory; she has revolving shifts. She started working there 9 months ago but she also sells cosmetics during her free time. She’s been in this line of work for 2 years. She is 41 years old, has been divorced for 10 years, and has two children who are 18 and 17 years old. Her oldest son lives at home and helps her with housework and her daughter is going to school in Cuenca. She does not own her own home, she rents. This is her first loan. A niece invited her to join this beautiful communal bank. She will use the funds to buy cosmetics so that her business may grow. Her goal is to have her own clothing store.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy eyeliner, eye shadow, lipsticks, creams, etc.

loans.name: Maricel

texts.en: Maricel O. is from the village of Rizal. She is 29 years old. Maricel is married and has three young children. To make a living, Maricel provides a transportation service. The main source of income for the business comes from operating a motorcycle-transport service. Maricel has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 3,200 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2006, Maricel joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maricel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to repair an existing vehicle for better service. Maricel is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase tires and other accessories. This will be the third loan taken out by Maricel from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand it. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Jackson Dan

texts.en:
Jackson Dan O. is a 34-year-old hardworking gentleman from Migori town, western Kenya. He is married to Rose Moraa who is formally employed. They have three children, Amos, Leviticus and Grace aged 13, 8 and 5 years respectively.

To make a living, Jackson owns a carpentry workshop in Migori town where he designs and constructs household items including tables, beds, etc. as per customer request. He is skilled in this art since he has done it for the last nine years. His carpentry shop is located in his homestead, so he has to maintain a good rapport with his clientele who come to order furniture and other items. Jackson is now requesting his third loan to buy timber, glue and additional carpentry tools. His aim is to maintain a good record with Kadet so that he will continue to qualify for future loans. His long term goal is to have a big workshop fully equipped with carpentry machines and at the same time own a timber yard.

loans.use: To buy timber for carpentry work.

loans.name: Visitacion

texts.en:
Visitacion P., from the village of Dalig Viejo, is 61 years old, married, and has seven adult-aged children. To make a living, for over five years Visitacion has been planting and harvesting a variety of vegetables for sale, earning approximately 6000 PHP a month.

In 2006, Visitacion joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan of 16000 PHP from ASKI that was used to purchase additional seeds and seedlings, she is now requesting a new loan of 17000 PHP to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be Visitacion's 11th loan from ASKI, and she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to save as a reserve for future emergencies.

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: John Litiema

texts.en:
John Litiema, a 61-year-old industrious man from Shinyalu town, Western Kenya, is married to Anjeline, a businesslady in the same town. They have two children, Rodgers and Rosemary, who are in secondary school.

John operates a carpentry workshop in Shinyalu market centre where he constructs household items such as tables and beds. He joined Kadet to access loans for his business after a friend introduced him to the organization, and he is now requesting his second loan after completing his first one without default. At the moment, John wants to diversify into poultry farming, and he plans to use this loan to buy poultry feed. He believes that by starting this other business, he will generate more income and improve his living standards.

John's longterm goal is to start a dairy farm to supply dairy products in Bungoma town.

loans.use: To buy poultry feed for his diversified business.

loans.name: Millicent Achieng

texts.en:
Millicent B. is a 33-year-old lady from Katito town, Western Kenya. She is married to William Onyango, an hotelier, and they have two children ages 15 and 1.

Millicent sells clothing in Katito town and has done this for the last eleven years. Through this business, she is able to support her family, since she makes a monthly income of 5,000 KES ($63). Her husband, too, supplements their income through his hotel business.

She is taking out her first loan from Kadet Limited, and she plans to use this loan to buy new clothing stock to sell. She plans to repay well without defaulting so that she may qualify for another loan.

She will use the profits to pay school fees for their children, and she hopes to make her family happy through improving their living standard.

loans.use: To buy new clothing to sell

loans.name: Estrellita

texts.en:
Estrellita B. is from the town of Baclayon. She is 66 years old. Estrellita is married and has three children. To make a living, Estrellita owns and operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling food and daily-use products in the local community. Estrellita has been engaged in her business for over 25 years.

In 2002, Estrellita joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Estrellita has successfully repaid previous loans from CEVI. Estrellita is requesting a new loan of 17,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 25th loan taken out by Estrellita from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children's tuition fees.

About CEVI: Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but, additionally, savings, insurance, and training, which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

loans.name: Alice Adhiambo

texts.en:
Alice Adhiambo is a 26-year-old modest lady in the heart of Kisumu city in Western Kenya. She is married to John Ogutu, who is in formal employment. They have two children ages five and two.

Alice operates a retail shop in Kisumu town where she makes a monthly income of 60,000 KES. She has operated this shop for the last three years, and she is grateful that she is able to meet her daily expenses and support her family. She joined Kadet Limited and took out a first loan, which she paid back successfully without default. She is now taking out a second loan, which she plans to use to build another shop, using part of it to stock her current shop.

Her profits will be used to expand the new shop. Her hopes are to open several branches and also ensure that her family has good living standards.

loans.use: To build another shop

loans.name: Silas Oyucho

texts.en:
Silas Oyucho is a Kenyan small-scale trader from Sondu in Kisumu town. He is married to Rosemary Anyango, who is a housewife. Silas has six children who all depend on him.

To make a living, Silas operates a retail business where he sells household goods like soaps, detergents and many more items in his neighborhood in Sondu town. He makes a monthly income of 7,000 Kenyan shillings (about $87), which goes to meet his family’s daily expenses. He has operated this business for the last 18 years and he believes that if he had  gotten access to loans earlier, then he could have grown his business. However, he is determined and has taken a second loan to buy more household stock for sale.

His desire is to always meet the expectations of his clients by stocking what they usually want. The sky is the limit and he is looking for Kiva lenders to help him meet his target.

loans.use: To buy stock of household products for sale

loans.name: Serekbai

texts.en: Serekbai S. is a 40 year old widow who lives with her five children in Bayan-Ulgiy province, in western Mongolia in their own ger-a traditional nomadic housing tent. Her elder two children are students while the younger three children attend a local middle school. Serekbai currently operates a meat retailing business in her town. She began her business in 1994 and has gained much experience. In 2008, her husband passed away so she was left to raise her children alone. Serekbai is a very hardworking woman who has a great business mind. She is optimistic about the future and has been making plans to expand her business. She says, "My only wish is to raise healthy children and to help them become well educated, good people in the future". Serekbai is requesting a 750,000 MNT loan to purchase more inventory for her meat retailing business.

loans.use: To purchase inventory.

loans.name: Caroline Akinyi

texts.en:
Caroline O. is a 34 year old lady from Sondu, Western Kenya. She is married to George Muga, a businessman, and they have one child.

Caroline operates a pharmacy shop in Sondu town where she sells various kinds of medicine over the counter. From the business, she is able to make a monthly income of KES 10,000 ($127) with which she is able to meet her family's expenses. She has a wide of experience in the business, having operated the shop for the past five years. She is taking her second loan from Kadet Limited. She plans to purchase different kinds of medicine that are required by her clients.

From the profits she anticipates to make, Caroline plans to become a wholesale pharmacist. Her future plans are to build her own house and to improve her standard of living.

loans.use: To buy stock of medicine.

loans.name: Evelyn Anyango

texts.en:
Evelyn Anyango is a 30 year old lady from Kisumu City who is married to Norbert Oduor. They have two daughters, Sylivia, nine years old and Grace, three years old. They live at Brilliant estate in the heart of Kisumu city.

Evelyn runs a water business, whereby she sells water to residents within her estate. Selling water in Kisumu city is big business due to a scarcity of the commodity in the area. Due to this fact, Evelyn has a ready market for her business. She makes a monthly income of KES 12,000 ($152). She is taking her first loan from Kadet Limited and she plans to use this money to buy better water pipes for her business. Evelyn will also use part of the money to expand her other business, second hand clothing.

Evelyn describes herself as an ambitious lady and her great ambition in the future is to buy water tanks for water storage during dry season. She also wants her two daughters to have access to better education.

loans.use: To buy better water pipes for the business.

loans.name: Eladia

texts.en:
Eladia M., photographed at the front of her restaurant, is from the town of Loon. She is 66 years old. Eladia is separated from her spouse. To make a living, Eladia owns and operates a restaurant serving local foods to customers in her community. Eladia has been in her business for over 20 years.

Eladia joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Eladia has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. She is requesting a new loan of 50,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. She plans to save the additional revenue from the business as a reserve for future emergencies. 

Asenso loans are a new product offered by CEVI for clients showing strong performance in previous loans, and who need a larger loan in order to continue to develop. CEVI recognises the importance of helping people out of poverty, as well as providing continuous support and training as these clients progress. CEVI aims to provide financial services, not only to our poorest clients, but also to our developing clients who should be rewarded for the way in which they display promising business skills. Please help us provide support for these clients.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Ahilbek

texts.en: Ahilbek E. is 48 years old and lives with his family in Bayan-Ulgiy province, western Mongolia, in a traditional housing tent called a "ger." Ahilbek operates a transportation service business in his town using a small car which he purchased in 2008. He transports people back and forth during the weekends throughout his town. He hopes to use his earnings as working capital and to stabilize his business. Ahilbek is requesting a 500,000 MNT loan to purchase spare parts for his car.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts for his car

loans.name: Stephen Ouma

texts.en: Stephen Ouma is a 27-year-old experienced furniture seller in Kibuye, a busy open air-market in the outskirts of Kisumu City. He is married to Lilian Ojwang, a housewife, and they have a five-month-old daughter. They live in Obunga estate, a low-income settlement in Kisumu. Ouma has been doing this business for the last three years and he has great plans to expand. He recently took out a loan from Kadet Ltd to buy more furniture for sale. His intention is to surpass his monthly income of Kshs 10,000 ($250). With the profits, he plans to pay his wife’s college fee because he wants to empower her through education. His dream is to continue working hard in his business to generate more income and improve his family’s living standards.

loans.use: To buy furniture for sale.

loans.name: Ahit

texts.en: Ahit S. is 44 years old and lives with his wife and two children in Bayan-Ulgiy province, western Mongolia, in a traditional nomadic housing tent called a "ger." His elder son Bazarbek, who is 22, works for a local private company while the younger son is a student. Ahit operates a food retailing business with the help of his wife. He began his business in 2002 in a small room of his house, but expanded his operation and set up a small shop called "Tsetsegt" two years later with working capital of 500,000 MNT. His wife is responsible for their food retailing business. Ahit has purchased a small car with his business earnings as well as his son's salary and has started running a taxi service in his town. He hopes to continue his success in the future and says, "My wife and I are working hard to save money for our son's education." He is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to increase his working capital.

loans.use: To increase working capital

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca G. is from the village of Luna. She is 52 years old and married with three adult children. To make a living, Rebecca owns a general store selling a variety of different products. She has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 2500 PHP a month. 

In 2006, Rebecca joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7000 PHP from ASKI and is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the eighth loan taken out by Rebecca from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Evaline Akinyi

texts.en: Evaline Akinyi, aged 46 years, is married to Malachi O. and they have six children. They live in Ojino Okiewo estate in the outskirts of Kisumu city. Evaline sells clothes in the same estate and has been in this business for the last two years. She buys the clothes from wholesale vendors and sells them at a profit in her stall. Evaline joined KADET Ltd to get access to loans to boost her business. With the first loan, she plans to buy more clothing for sale. She is optimistic about the loan since she has ambitions to grow the business in scale, purchase stock in large quantities, get more profits, and open another branch in Kisumu town. Her dream is to become a leading supplier of clothes in Kisumu city.

loans.use: To buy clothing for sale.

loans.name: Bulgan

texts.en:
Bulgan J. is 25 years old and lives with her husband and son in Hovd province, western Mongolia. She and her family live in their own ger – a traditional nomadic housing tent. Her husband is a teacher in a middle school while her son goes to a local kindergarten. Bulgan began her shoe trading business in 2009. After two years of hard work, she was able to increase the type and quantity of her products, which she has been selling at a local market called "Ih Buyant".
Bulgan wants to expand her business even further by introducing new product lines from Uvs province, western Mongolia. With these new product lines, she hopes to grow her customer base. She dreams of using her business revenue to own a small retail shop. Bulgan is requesting a 1,500,000 MNT loan so that she can purchase "white-sole boots" at wholesales prices from Uvs province.

loans.use: To purchase inventory

loans.name: Agnes Silantoi

texts.en:
Agnes Silantoi O. is 34 years old, married to Moses O., and has four children. She is a farmer who owns her own piece of land, which she has been farming for the last four years.
Agnes learned about Kiva partner, KADET, from a KADET client who was already a registered member in her area of residence. This will be Agnes' second loan, for 20,000 KES, which she is planning to spend on pesticides to spray her growing wheat to prevent it being invaded by pests. She hopes to use the profits from her loan to expand her farming activity from small-scale to commercial farming.
Agnes' dream is to practise large-scale farming and attain financial independence. She is a hardworking woman who is determined to achieve her goals.

loans.use: To purchase pesticides for her growing wheat

loans.name: Byambasuren

texts.en:
Byambasuren D. is 48 years old and lives with her husband and two daughters in Tuv province, central Mongolia. She and her family have been living together in their own apartment for 16 years. Her husband is a security guard for a local private company, her elder daughter works for APU LLC as an accountant while her youngest daughter is a student.
Byambasuren runs a vegetable and grocery retail business at a local market in her town. She uses her business revenues to cover her family's daily needs and her younger daughter's tuition fees. Byambasuren is focused on the future and has plans to own a small food shop in her town. She says, "I want to improve my business so I can buy a shop." Byambasuren is requesting a 800,000 MNT loan to purchase more stock for her vegetable and grocery retail business.

loans.use: To purchase inventory

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 48-year-old married man and father of four children from Lebanon. He has owned a small sweets and candies shop in his town since 1995. Over the years, thanks to his business' income, he has been able to meet his children’s needs. He is well known in his town, where all the kids pass by his shop to buy his delicious products, and he receives them with a large smile. Today, he is requesting a $1000 loan to buy additional sweets and to offer a wider variety of products to his little clients, in order to increase his sales and therefore his income.

Note: Based on the political and social challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e., blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, not indicating his/her name and location, etc.) Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Lebanon's borrowers.

About Ameen:
Ameen s.a.l. has been a major player in the Lebanese Microfinance sector since 1999. Originally, a micro-credit program created by CHF International, Ameen evolved to become Ameen s.a.l. in 2003, a Lebanese services company. In 2007, Ameen s.a.l. registered with the Central Bank of Lebanon to become the first Lebanese financial institution specialized in Microfinance.

At Ameen s.a.l. we pledge to provide financial services to the largest number of micro and small entrepreneurs and to the working poor, to help them develop their businesses and improve their incomes.

Ameen has been able to use its interest-free loans Kiva to offer lower-interest loans with faster disbursement for their micro-loan borrowers. Since its inception, Ameen has provided high-quality financial services to over 41,000 borrowers and disbursed over 81,000 loans totaling $115 million. To learn more about Ameen, please visit http://partners.kiva.org/partners/115

loans.use: To buy additional sweets

loans.name: Samarik Ole

texts.en:
Samarik Ole S. is a 24-year-old farmer who supports four members of his family. His spouse is Kiraposho S., who is also a farmer. They do the farming together on their own piece of land. He is been in farming activity for the last three years.

He learned about KADET through a friend who is a KADET registered client in his area of residence. This will be his first loan. He is planning to spend 20,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) on harrowing, 20,000 KES on seeds and fertilizer, and 10,000 KES on planting 10 acres of wheat.

He hopes to use the profit from the proceeds of this loan to expand his farming activity from small-scale to large-scale commercial farming.

Samarik's dream is to do large-scale farming and buy his own farm machinery. He is a hardworking, determined man.

loans.use: To spend on harrowing, seeds, fertilizer and planting wheat

loans.name: Byambatsetseg

texts.en: Byambatsetseg L. is 41 years old and lives with her husband and four children in Tuv province, central of Mongolia, in their own apartment. Her elder daughters are students, while the youngest two children attend a local middle school. Byambatsetseg operates a cosmetic goods trading business at a local trading center in her town with the help of her husband. Her husband also works at a local Inspection Agency as a senior inspector to supplement their income. Byambatsetseg started her business in 2003 and since then, she has quickly grown her business over the past years and has built a strong customer base. Byambatsetseg hopes to build on her experience in the future and says, "I want to expand my business and have my own spa center, as well as manage a retail clothing business." She is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to purchase a car for her business.

loans.use: To purchase a car

loans.name: Duncan Pempa

texts.en:
Duncan Pempa N. is 25 years old and married to Sayialel N.. He supports two people in his family. Duncan is a farmer and he does the farming on his own piece of land, which he has been doing for the last three years.

He learned about KADET through a friend who is a KADET registered client in his area of residence. This will be his first loan. He is planning to use 20,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) on harrowing, 20,000 KES on seeds and fertilizer and 10,000 KES on planting 10 acres of wheat.

He hopes to use the profit from the proceeds of this loan to expand his farming activity from small-scale to commercial farming.

Duncan's dream is to do large-scale farming and attain financial independence. He is a hardworking man who is determined to achieve his set goals.

loans.use: To use on harrowing, seeds, fertilizer and planting wheat

loans.name: Lemomo Ole

texts.en:
Lemomo Ole S. is a 30 year old farmer who supports four members of his family. His spouse is Melina S. who is also a farmer. They do the farming together on their own piece of land. Lemomo has been farming wheat for the last six years. This will be his second loan. He is planning to spend 20,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) to buy fertilizer and seeds, and 10,000 KES is to be used on planting his five-acre wheat farm.

He is anticipating buying some farm machinery with the profit from the expanded farming activity.

His hope and dream for his business and family is that he will become a large-scale farmer and be financially stable, so that he can educate his children and build a nice house.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, seeds and plant his five acre wheat farm

loans.name: Erkujek

texts.en: Erkujek B. is 46 years old and lives with his wife and three children in Bayan-Ulgiy province, in western Mongolia, in their own ger, a traditional nomadic housing tent. His two elder children are students, the youngest one goes to a local middle school and his wife helps him with his business. Erkujek operates a machinery spare parts trading business and owns a private shop in his home where he sells his products. He began his business in 2000 with a small wooden shop and after years of successful business operation, Erkujek managed to enlarge the shop and expand his services. Since running the business successfully, their business revenues and working capital have obviously increased, so that Erkujek could afford his children's tuition fees. During the summertime, he engages in a taxi service while his wife Nina is responsible for their machinery parts sales business. Erkujek is requesting a 2,200,000 MNT loan to increase his business working capital and to purchase used cars in order to dismantle and resell their spare parts.

loans.use: To increase working capital

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 38-year-old married man from Lebanon. He has 2 young children who attend school. He has owned a car repair shop and specializes in car body work. He has been involved in this occupation for more than 15 years. With his experience, he has been able to gain a good number of clients asking for his reparation services. He works hard, as he is the only family provider, to support the heavy expenses of his life and to pay for his children's schooling. He plans to make some modifications and expand his shop and to do so, he is asking to borrow $1000 from Kiva's partner Ameen s.a.l. to buy additional tools.

Note: Based on the political and social challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him (i.e., blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his picture, not indicating his name and location, etc.) Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Lebanon's borrowers.

About Ameen:
Ameen s.a.l. has been a major player in the Lebanese microfinance sector since 1999. Originally, a micro-credit program created by CHF International, Ameen evolved to become Ameen s.a.l. in 2003, a Lebanese services company. In 2007, Ameen s.a.l. registered with the Central Bank of Lebanon to become the first Lebanese financial institution specialized in microfinance.

At Ameen s.a.l. we pledge to provide financial services to the largest number of micro and small entrepreneurs and to the working poor, to help them develop their businesses and improve their incomes.

Ameen has been able to use its interest-free loans with Kiva to offer lower-interest loans with faster disbursement for their micro-loan borrowers. Since its inception, Ameen has provided high-quality financial services to over 41,000 borrowers and disbursed over 81,000 loans totaling $115 million. To learn more about Ameen, please visit http://partners.kiva.org/partners/115

loans.use: buy additional tools

loans.name: Nchue

texts.en: Nchue K. is 27 years old and single. He has been farming on his own piece of land for the last five years. He learned about KADET through an awareness program run by KADET staff in his area of residence. This will be his first loan. He plans to spend 10,000 KES to plough land, 20,000 KES on harrowing, 18,000 KES on seeds and 10,000 KES on planting his ten acre wheat farm. He hopes to use the profit from the proceeds of this loan to expand his farming activity from small scale to commercial. Nchue's dream is to do large scale farming, attain financial independence and buy his own farm machinery. He is a hardworking man who is determined to achieve his set goals.

loans.use: to plough, harrow and plant his ten acre wheat farm and to buy seeds

loans.name: Elsa

texts.en:
Elsa M. is from the town of Loon. She is 38 years old, married and has 7 school-aged children. Elsa owns and operates a business making and selling cooked food for daily meals. 

Elsa joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elsa has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. She is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Elsa from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children's tuition fees. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, it has numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Irine Sekeyian

texts.en:
Irine Sekeyian K. is 35 years old. She is married to Daniel Saoli and is the mother of two school-aged children. Irine has been farming on her own piece of land for the last ten years.

She learned about KADET through an awareness program run by KADET staff in her area of residence. This will be her first loan. She is planning to spend Kshs. 20,000  on harrowing,Kshs. 10,000  on seeds and on planting ten acres of wheat. With the profits she hopes to make from the proceeds of this loan, she intends to plant wheat on a bigger piece of land. Her future dream is to be able to buy a bigger piece of land where she can do commercial farming. Irine believes she is hardworking and only needs the resources necessary to attain her dreams.

loans.use: to harrow and plant ten acres of wheat and to buy seeds

loans.name: Azima's Group

texts.en:
Azima A. is the leader of this group. She is 76 and a widow. She has raised a son, who is 53 and works as a private driver. In order to make money, Azima has been breeding livestock since 1990. She buys sheep at a low price and then resells them after fattening. Azima makes 1,000 KGS per month. With the money received from this loan, she wants to purchase two sheep for breeding. In the future, she plans to increase the number of her livestock.

Kulpunai G., 22, is married and has a newborn daughter. Since 2000, Kulpunai and her husband have been engaged in wholesale trading of fruits and vegetables. They started with an initial investment of 15,000 KGS and now make 9,000 KGS per month. Kuplunai applied for this loan because she wants to increase her business turnover and purchase various fruits and vegetables in order to resell them at a higher price.

Kadirjan S., 53, is married and has a son and a daughter. His son works in construction and his daughter helps at home with the housework. Kadirjan and his wife have been engaged in cattle breeding for 20 years, selling cattle after fattening them. Kadirjan makes 2,000 KGS per month. With the money received from this loan, he wants to purchase a bull for breeding.

Santalat A. is the treasurer of the group. She is 54, married and has three sons and a daughter. The older son went to work in Russia, the second son works in construction, the third is engaged in cattle breeding and the daughter is a student. Santalat and her husband have been breeding cattle for 25 years, reselling the cattle after fattening. They make 4,000 KGS per month. Santalat wants to increase their number of cattle, so she applied for this loan to purchase bull-calves for breeding. --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase two sheep

loans.name: Lemeria Ole

texts.en:
Lemeria Ole L. is 45 years old. He is married to Silivia L. and is the father of one child. Lemeria has been farming on his own piece of land for the last eight years.

He learned about KADET from a marketing awareness program run by KADET staff in his area. This will be his first loan. He is planning to spend the 20,000 KES to prepare his land for planting more maize, which has proved to do very well due to fertile land and adequate rainfall in this area. With the profits he hopes to make from the proceeds of this loan, he plans to plough more land for farming to increase his maize production. His future dream is to become a large scale maize farmer in his area. He is a hardworking man who is determined to achieve his set goals.

loans.use: to prepare his land for planting more maize

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy merchandise

loans.name: Kiranta Enole

texts.en:
Kiranta Enole S. is 33 years old. She is married to Naseyian Nkurumwa and is the mother of two school-aged children. She has been farming on her own piece of land for the last five years.

Kiranta learned about KADET through an awareness program run by KADET staff in her area of residence. This will be her first loan. She is planning to spend 50,000 KES to prepare the land and plant wheat. With the profits she hopes to make from the proceeds of this loan, she intends to plant wheat on a larger piece of land. Her future dream is to be able to buy a bigger piece of land where she can do commercial farming. Kiranta believes she is hardworking and only needs the necessary resources to attain her goals.

loans.use: to prepare the land and plant wheat

loans.name: Julia

texts.en:
Julia B. is from the village of Brgy. Abinganan, Bambang, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 49 years old, married and has 4 school-aged children. Julia owns and operates a business raising livestock, primarily pigs, for fattening and sale. Julia has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP when she sells her raised animal.

In 2008, Julia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Julia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from ASKI, which was used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. Julia is requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Julia from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children's tuition fees.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Moustapha

texts.fr: Monsieur Moustapha F. est un jeune mécanicien célibataire âgé de 30 ans .Il est propriétaire de taxi clando dont il a reçu financement au niveau de la caisse pour complément d'acquisition . En ce moment ce véhicule est tombé en panne et Mr F. vient solliciter un nouveau crédit pour l'achat d'un moteur et reprendre l'activité de taxi qui lui procurait des rentrées de fonds pour aider ses parents qui vivent dans un village situé à une dizaine de kilomètres de Mbour et également payer son loyer là où il continue à pratiquer son métier de mécanicien
texts.en:
Mr. Moustapha F. is a young mechanic who is single and 30 years old. He owns a clandestine taxi and got a loan from the institution in order to complete the acquisition of this. At present this vehicle is broken down and Mr. F. has just requested a new loan in order to buy an engine and resume his taxi business. This will allow him to get some income to help his parents who live in a village around ten kilometers from Mbour, and also to pay his rent at the place where he is carrying out his trade as a mechanic.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of an engine

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
Marites B. is from the village of Barangay Abinganan, Bambang, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 39 years old, married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Marites owns and operates a general store selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste to the local community. Marites has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Marites joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marites has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell.

Marites is requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be the 6th loan taken out by Marites from ASKI.  She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the pioneer microfinance institutions in the Philippines committed to serve the needy in Central and Northern Luzon through socio-economic development and holistic transformation.

 *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Mawuli Kokou

texts.fr: D. est un jeune homme célibataire très dynamique, afin de se prendre en charge et de subvenir à ses propres besoins, il s'est lancée en 2008 dans le commerce de produits d'alimentation générale, il exerce ce commerce dans une petite boutique, il a 2 ans d'ancienneté dans ce commerce. il a déjà obtenu du crédit de WAGES qu'il a remboursé, il sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour l'achat de divers produits d'alimentation générale.
texts.en:
D. is a young single man who is very dynamic. In order to provide for his own needs, he set himself up in the general food products business in 2008. He carries out this business in a small shop and has two years' experience. He has already had a loan from WAGES which he paid back, and he is requesting another loan from WAGES to buy various general food products.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of general food products

loans.name: Glerita

texts.en: Glerita B. is from the village of Barnagay Abingnan, Bambang, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 44 years old, married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Glerita owns and operates a business raising livestock for breeding. Glerita has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month from these activities. In 2009, Glerita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Glerita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase breeding livestock. Glerita is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed and medicines. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Glerita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the pioneer microfinance institutions in the Philippines committed to serve the needy in Central and Northern Luzon through socio-economic development and holistic transformation. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed and medicines

loans.name: Ozodahon's Group

texts.en: Ozodahon S. is the leader of this group. She is 27 and divorced. She works as a seller of Oriflame cosmetics. She also owns some land and cultivates different fruits and vegetables. Selling some part of her harvest, Ozodahon makes 4,000 soms per month. With money received from the loan, she wants to purchase fertilizers which are needed for farming. Barno M., 38, is married. Her husband went to work in Russia to earn some money. She has two sons and two daughters. All the children study at school except the youngest daughter. Barno owns some land on which she cultivates cotton and rice. She has been doing this for 16 years. Selling some part of her harvest, she makes 4,000 soms per month. With the money received from the loan, she wants to purchase mineral fertilizers for growing cotton and rice. In the future she plans to build a new house for her older son. Dilfuzahon A. is the treasurer of the group. She is 37 and divorced. She has a son and a daughter and both of them are at school. Two years ago, with the initial investment of 300 soms, Dilfuzahon started to sell convenience goods at her home, saved some money and then opened a kiosk near her house. She applied for the loan because she needs money to purchase various goods in order to increase the turnover of her business. Mamura R. is 25. She has been working in a sewing workshop for two years. With money received from the loan she wants to purchase a sewing machine. In the future she plans to open her own sewing workshop. ====================================== --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers for farming

loans.name: Améyo

texts.fr: en 2008, cette jeune s'est lancée dans le commerce de détail de cartes de recharges téléphoniques, elle s'approvisionne auprès des sociétés de téléphonie de la place, pour toucher plus de clients, elle fait son commerce de façon ambulante. actuellement son stock de cartes de recharges est en baisse raison pour laquelle elle sollicite de WAGES un prêt pour gonfler son stock de cartes de recharges avec l'achat de 50 cartes ILLICO, 50 cartes TOGOCEL et 50 cartes MOOV. elle a une personne à charge.
texts.en:
In 2008 this young lady began retailing telephone top-up cards. She gets her supplies from the local telephone companies, and in order to reach more customers, she carries out her business on a door-to-door basis. Currently her stock of top-up cards is low, and she is thus requesting a loan from WAGES in order to boost this stock with the purchase of 50 Illico cards, 50 Togocel cards and 50 Moov cards. She has one person in her care.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of top-up cards

loans.name: Isabel

texts.en:
Isabel E. is from the town of Panglao. She is 49 years old. Isabel is married and has 6 children. Her eldest is aged 30. Her younger children still go to school and she hopes for them to finish college someday. To make a living, Isabel owns & operates a service-based business. The main source of income for the business comes from providing laundry services in the local community. Isabel has been engaged in her business for over 8 years. She wants to start raising hogs so she would have an extra source of income. 

Isabel joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Isabel has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Isabel is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide service. She also plans to buy piglets to raise. This will be the eleventh loan taken out by Isabel from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase materials for laundry and buy piglets to raise

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria A. K. is thirty years old, married, and has one child aged two. Her business is located at Kakamega. She has been selling such items as detergents, sugar, flour, rice, bread and others for the last two years to the local people. She says that this business is profitable and the major challenge she has is there are so many people doing the same kind of business as hers in the area and so customers are spoilt for choice. However she works very hard to keep her business doing well. 

She is using her loan of Kes 20,000 to buy more general items to expand her business. Her husband is a teacher and supports her in the business and they hope to bring up their children in a good environment and provide  basic needs for them. She sees her business growing into a supermarket in future. She describes herself as patient and ambitious.

loans.use: sugar, flour, rice, bread, detergents and other items

loans.name: Yun

texts.en:
