Mrs. Yun S., 31 ( in the photo), is a widow with one son and one daughter. Her daughter is a garment factory worker and her son attends school. The family lives in a small village in a suburb of Phnom Penh City.  

Yun has been a garment factory worker for more than ten years.  She is applying for a loan of US$ 1,000 to build a concrete brick room under her wooden house. She also will use a part of the loan to build a restroom for the family.

loans.use: To build a concrete brick room under her wooden house and a restroom

loans.name: Marie

texts.fr: cette femme exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de produits d'alimentation générale, elle fait ce commerce depuis près de 5 ans déjà, elle exerce son commerce dans le marché local d'akodessewa et s'approvisionne le plus souvent au marché d'adawlato. son stock de marchandise a baissé et elle n'arrive pas à satisfaire la demande de ses clients raison pour laquelle elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour l'achat de 4 paniers de tomates, 6 bidons d'huile NIOTO, 4 cartons de pâtes alimentaires et divers autres produits alimenatires. elle est marié, elle n'a pas d'enfant, elle vit avec sa famille dans le quartier d'attiégou
texts.en:
This woman makes a living selling general food products. She has been doing this for almost five years. She carries on this activity in the local market of Akodessewa and usually gets her stocks at the Adawlato market. Her stocks are currently depleted, and she is unable to meet customer demand. Therefore, she is seeking a loan from WAGES to purchase 4 baskets of tomatoes, 6 cans of NIOTO oil, 4 boxes of pasta and various other food items. She is married, has no children, and she lives with her family in the neighborhood of Attiégou.

Translated from French by Nathalie Pelletier, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase general food products

loans.name: Sreytoch

texts.en:
Mrs. Sreytoch S. (in the picture) is 46 years old  and her husband, Mr. Vichet Touch, is 42 years old. They have been married since 1991 and have two sons who are mechanics. They live in a small village outside of Phnom Penh City. 

Sreytoch has been a garment factory worker for ten years, while her husband has been a mechanic for two years. She does not have her own transportation so she spends a lot of money for traveling costs. It’s difficult for her to manage their income to support her family. 

That’s why she is requesting her first loan in the amount of US$ 1,000 to purchase a motorbike for commuting. She will be able to cut down on some expenses by not spending so much on traveling costs any more.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle for commuting.

loans.name: Marineth

texts.en:
Marineth M. is from the village of Brgy. Abinganan, Bambang, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 40 years old. Marineth is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Marineth owns & operates a tailoring business.The main source of income for the business comes from providing general alteration & tailoring services to local community members. Marineth has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Marineth joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marineth has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional fabrics & materials. Marineth is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional tailoring equipment such as needles & thread. This will be the second loan taken out by Marineth from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional tailoring equipment such as needles & thread

loans.name: Otgonbayar

texts.en: Otgonbayar M., 27 years old, lives with his wife and son in a ger, a  traditional Mongolian nomadic tent, in Hovd Province, located in western Mongolia.  His wife works as a baker for a local bakery company, while Otgonbayar operates a transportation service business which he started in 2008. He hopes to continue to grow and improve his business so that he can provide for his family and create a permanent workplace with regular customers. A very hardworking and creative person, Otgonbayar is requesting a 1,300,000 MNT loan to purchase spare parts for his taxi.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts for his car

loans.name: Koinet Ole

texts.en:
Koinet Ole D. is a single 23-year-old who has been rearing sheep for the last four years. He buys young rams during dry season when they are not costly, placing them on his farm which he has fenced for grazing. After the rainy season when the rams have fattened, he sells them for a profit.

Koinet Ole learned about KADET from marketing awareness conducted by KADET staff in his area and is now requesting his first loan to buy more sheep to fatten and later sell at a profit. With the anticipated profits he intends to acquire a bigger piece of land and fence it for grazing. A hardworking man who is determined to achieve his goals, Koinet Ole plans to become a large scale sheep-rearing farmer. .

loans.use: To buy more sheep for fattening to sell later.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: buying two new sewing machines

loans.name: Caleb

texts.en:
Caleb Z. is fifty-six years old, married, and has six children. They hope to teach their children good business skills so that even the grandchildren will enjoy the benefits of business. His business is located at Chanduma market near a college in Kakamega. He has been selling scrap metal, cookers and other items for the last 20 years. He sells to local people and has two employees. He says that this business is profitable and the major challenge he has is financial constraints. However, he works very hard to keep his business doing well. 

He is using his loan of Kes 30,000 to buy more scrap metal to make cookers to sell to the local people. He hopes to grow his business and open other outlets in future. He describes himself as very polite, honest, and aggressive.

loans.use: Scrap Metal

loans.name: Musuuri Ole

texts.en:
Musuuri Ole N. is 24 years old .He a single young man who is focused on farming. He does sheep rearing which he has been doing for the last five years. His target is to buy young rams during the dry season when they are not very costly, then place them in his farm which he has fenced purposely for grazing. After the rainy season when the rams have fattened, he sells them at a higher price and earns some profit.

He learned about KADET from marketing awareness done by KADET staff in his area. This will be his first loan which he is planning to use to buy more sheep for fattening to sell latter at a profit. With the anticipated profit he intends to acquire a bigger piece of land and fence it for grazing.

His future dream is that he will become a large-scale farmer in sheep rearing. He is a hardworking man and very determined to achieve his set goals.

loans.use: buy sheep to fatten and sell later

loans.name: Jeremiah Saiyalel

texts.en:
Jeremiah Sayialel K. is 32 years old. He is married to Nalinkunkera K. and he is the father of two children. Jeremiah is a farmer and he does the farming on his own piece of land which he has been doing for the last three years.

He learned about KADET from marketing awareness done by KADET staff in his area. This will be his first loan. He is planning to spend the twenty thousand to prepare land for planting more maize; maize has proved to be doing very well due to fertile lands in the area. With the profits he hopes to make from this loan, he plans to hire more land for farming to increase his maize production and also start planting other farm produce like beans and potatoes. 

His future dream is that he will become a large-scale farmer owning farm machinery. He is a hardworking man who is determined to achieve his set goals.

loans.use: prepare land for planting more maize

loans.name: Na We Cam-Ii Group

texts.en:
Here are members of the “Na We Cam II” group from the northern city of Makeni. They are small-scale businesswomen who have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva.org, to apply for a loan of SLL 500,000 for each to enable them to expand their businesses. 

Pictured left is Emma B. who is the leader of this group. The fifty-year-old Emma is married with five children – three in primary school and two adults. For many years now, Emma has been selling palm oil (the country’s most popular cooking oil). She also sells containers (used mainly to store palm oil). With her share of the loan, Emma will buy gallons of palm oil and a number of containers to add to her current ones.

loans.use: buy gallons of palm oil and containers to add to her current ones

loans.name: Sharofat's Group

texts.en:
Sharofat H. leads this loan group. She is 55 years old, married, and has two sons. One works in Russia, while the other works in construction with his father. Ten years ago Sharofat invested 10,000 soms in a business that sells fruits and vegetables, and now makes 5,000 soms per month. She will use her portion of this loan to buy more produce to sell to her customers. 

Karimahan A., 55, is a widow with two sons. One works in Russia and the other is a farmer. Five years ago, she used a 5,000 soms investment to go into business as a cook. She will use her portion of this new loan to buy a calf for breeding. 

Sapilahon S., 41, is married and has a daughter and a son. Her son is a student and her daughter makes dresses. Two years ago, she used 1,000 soms to begin making dresses and curtains. She now earns 3,000 soms a month, and has applied for a new loan to buy fabric to make more items to sell to her customers. 

Bubuyahon H. is the treasurer of this group. She is 38, married and has two sons and one daughter. Her sons are at school but her daughter is too young to enroll yet. Her husband works in Russia. She plans to use her portion of this loan to buy the materials she needs to do needed repairs to her house.  

Sapilahon B., 58, is a widow who has raised one son and two daughters, Her son works in construction and her daughters are married and live with their families. Eleven years ago, she took a 3,000 som investment to go into business selling fruits and vegetables.  She now makes 4,000 soms a month, and plans to use her portion of this loan to buy potatoes and cucumbers to sell to her customers.  In the future, she plans to expand her business and start repairing her house. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
 This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 

MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the three principles of People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (being environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and see a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to buy fruits and vegetables to sell to her customers

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 47-year-old married man with three children from Lebanon. He is the main income provider for his family. He has 27 years of experience working as a farmer, having had his own farm since 1995. He uses plastic tents to grow his products. These tents also allow him to better monitor product quality as well as to grow his products for more months during the year. He works independently in his business. Today, he is requesting a loan of $1000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase needed supplies for his farm and a special machine to cultivate the land. He estimates that the loan will help him increase his profits by 15%. 

Note: Based on the political and social challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e., blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, not indicating his/her name and location, etc.) Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Lebanon's borrowers.

About Ameen:
Ameen s.a.l. has been a major player in the Lebanese Microfinance sector since 1999. Originally, a micro-credit program created by CHF International, Ameen evolved to become Ameen s.a.l. in 2003, a Lebanese services company. In 2007, Ameen s.a.l. registered with the Central Bank of Lebanon to become the first Lebanese financial institution specialized in Microfinance.

At Ameen s.a.l. we pledge to provide financial services to the largest number of micro and small entrepreneurs and to the working poor, to help them develop their businesses and improve their incomes.

Ameen has been able to use its interest-free loans from Kiva to offer lower-interest loans with faster disbursement for their micro-loan borrowers. Since its inception, Ameen has provided high-quality financial services to over 41,000 borrowers and disbursed over 81,000 loans totaling $115 million. To learn more about Ameen, please visit http://partners.kiva.org/partners/115

loans.use: purchase needed supplies for his farm and a machine to cultivate the land.

loans.name: Paul

texts.en: Paul K. G. is fourty seven years old and married with two children aged twenty six and twenty one years old. His business is located at Thika town. (Thika is the region in Kenya known for production of pineapples.) He provides transportation to the local people and has been in this business for the last thirteen years. He says that his business is profitable but the major challenge is the high cost of maintenance since any car breakdown slows the business. However he works very hard to keep it doing well. He is using his loan of Kes 20,000 to buy a new engine for his vehicle to provide better service to passengers. Paul wants to grow his business, and even diversify by opening a milk processing plant. He also raises cows and chickens. He describes himself as hard-working, humble, and optimistic.

loans.use: buy a new car engine.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buying grains

loans.name: Sky Group

texts.en:
Presented to you in the photo are the members of the “Sky” group from Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. These small-business entrepreneurs have come to SMT, a Kiva partner, for the very first time to apply for an SLL 500,000 loan for each to enable them to strengthen their businesses in terms of size and quality.

The leader of this group of entrepreneurs is 27-year-old Mariatu C., who is pictured in the left. She lives in Makeni together with her husband and two children.

Mariatu sells clothes: T-shirts, underwear, etc. With the help of this loan, she will be able to buy dozens of T-shirts and underwear to add to her stock.

loans.use: To buy dozens of T-shirts and underwear to add to her stock

loans.name: Ayié

texts.fr: A. est une dame mariée et très dynamique, elle est mariée et mère d'un enfant. elle vit avec sa famille dans le quartier d'attiégou. pour apporter sa contribution aux charges de son ménage, elle s'est lancée en 2006 dans le commerce de pagnes. elle s'approvisionne au grand marché de Lomé.elle exerce ce commerce de façon ambulante. elle voudrait rehausser son stock qui s'épuise, elle sollicite alors de WAGES un crédit pour l'achat de 10 pagnes Hitarget, 10 pagnes WAX et divers autre pagnes de différentes qualité.
texts.en:
Ms. A. is a married woman who is very energetic. She is the mother of one child and lives with her family in the Attiégou district. To cover her share of household expenses, she got started in the commerce of pagnes (colorful West African cloth) in 2006. She gets her supplies at the big market of Lomé. She operates her business door-to-door. She would like to enhance her stock of goods, which is shrinking. She is therefore requesting a loan from WAGES in order to buying 10 Hitarget pagnes, 10 WAX pagnes, and a variety of other pagnes of different qualities.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying traditional cloth

loans.name: Falila

texts.fr: K. falila exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de charbons de bois, elle fait ce commerce depuis  3 ans déjà.  elle s'approvisionne à l'intérieur du pays ce qui lui permet de gagner une plus grande marge bénéficiaire sur ses ventes. elle a déjà obtenu de WAGES un premier crédit qu'elle a bien remboursé.  ce deuxième prêt qu'elle sollicite va lui permettre de s'approvisionner avec 18 sacs de charbons de bois et assurer le transport de la marchandise. elle est mariée et elle a 2 personnes à sa charge.
texts.en:
K. Falila has a revenue-generating business involving charcoal. She has been in this business for three years already. She gets her supplies from the country's interior, and this enables her to earn a bigger profit margin on her sales. Falila has already had an initial loan from WAGES that she repaid. This second loan she is requesting is going to allow her to stock up with 18 sacks of charcoal and to ensure the transport of the merchandise. Falila is married and has two people to support.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying charcoal

loans.name: If God Gree Group

texts.en:
Presented to you in the photo are members of a solidarity lending group named “If God Gree”. They are small-scale-business people from Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. They have come to SMT, a Kiva partner, to apply for a loan of SLL 500,000 each to enable them expand their businesses.

The leader of the group is Hawa K., pictured on the left. 27-year-old Hawa is married and has four children: two in primary school and two not of school-going age.

Hawa sells laundry soaps and jewelry. With the help of this loan, she will be able to expand her business by buying more soaps and jewelry to add to her stock.

loans.use: To buy more laundry soaps and jewelry in large quantity to add to her stock

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to expand his shop

loans.name: Aigul's Group

texts.en:
Aigul A. is the leader of this group. She is 36 and married with a son who studies at school. Aigul works as a teacher of geometry and her husband is a private entrepreneur who buys fruit and vegetables in the village and resells it in the city. Eleven years ago, with the initial investment of 7000 soms, Aigul started to breed livestock. She has fourteen sheep and with money from the loan she wants to buy more sheep to breed. She will use part of the loan to start repairing her house. In the future she plans to build a new house.

Jyldyzhan U., 34, is married with two daughters and a son, all of them in school. Fifteen years ago, when she moved to the new house, her mother-in-law gave her a calf as a present. And since that moment Jyldyzkan has been engaged in cattle breeding. Every day she sells dairy products and she makes 1250 soms per month. With money received from the loan, Jyldyzkan wants to increase the number of cattle and purchase a cow.

Kunduzhon M., 34, is married and has two sons and two daughters. The older son is at school and the other children are not yet old enough. Kunduzhon breeds livestock and sells dairy products. Her husband went to work to Russia. With money received from the loan Kunduzhon wants to purchase two sheep.  

Sahadathon M. is the treasurer of the group. She is 55 and married. She has raised a son and three daughters. The son and the older daughter work in Bishkek, and the other daughters help Sahadathon with housework. Sahadathon breeds cattle. Every day she sells dairy products and makes 1250 soms per month. Her husband works as a driver, with a monthly salary of 5000 soms. With money from the loan, Sahadathon wants to purchase a cow to breed. In the future she wants to increase the number of cattle, get a good harvest, and save money to contribute to her daughter’s wedding.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line — People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (being environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support, and learn more about, Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team — Supporters of Kyrgyzstan — Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase livestock

loans.name: Kennedy

texts.en:
Kennedy K. is 36-years-old. He is married to Nalakite K. and has one child. Kennedy is a farmer who farms his own piece of land which he has been doing for the last eight years.

He learned about KADET from marketing awareness done by KADET staff in his area. This will be his first loan. He is planning to spend Ks 30,000 to buy fertilizer for his already growing maize and to pay for labour, and the remaining Ks 10,000 to prepare the land to plant more maize. (Maize does very well in the area's fertile land and good rainfall.) With the profits he hopes to make from the proceeds of this loan, he plans to plough more land for farming to increase his maize production. 

His dream is to become a large-scale maize farmer owning some farm machinery. He is a hard-working man, determined to achieve his set goals.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer for his maize and labour to prepare land to plant more maize

loans.name: Adjéoda

texts.fr: ce monsieur est un  homme marié avec 2 enfants, il vit avec sa femme et ses enfants dans le quartier de hedzranawoé qui est un quartier de la ville de Lomé. il a appris la menuiserie, il a ouvert son propre atelier dans lequel il fabrique et vend des meubles à partir du bois. actuellement il a reçu des commandes qu'il ne peut satisfaire parce qu'il ne dispose plus de bois, il sollicite chez WAGES un prêt qui puisse lui permettre d'acheter  du bois et satisfaire la demande de sa clientèle.
texts.en:
This gentleman is married with two children, and lives with his wife and children in the Hedzranawoé borough of Lomé. He learned carpentry and opened his own workshop, where he builds and sells wooden furniture. He currently has orders he is unable to honor because he is out of wood. He is therefore requesting a loan from WAGES that will enable him to buy wood and satisfy customer demand.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buy wood and other materials

loans.name: Koko

texts.fr: O. koko est une jeune femme célibataire et très dynamique, pour pouvoir subvenir à ses propres besoin, elle s'est lancée il y a un an dans le commerce de bijoux. elle s'approvisionne au grand marché de Lomé. sa clientèle se compose de toutes personnes. son stock de bijoux s'épuise, elle souhaite se réapprovisionner raison pour laquelle elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour l'achat de bijoux de différentes qualités afin d'accroître ses recettes et satisfaire les besoins de ses clients.
texts.en:
Koko O. is a young single woman who is very dynamic. In order to provide for her needs, she started selling jewelry a year ago. She gets her supplies at the large market in Lomé. Her customer base is made up of all types of people. Since her stock of jewelry is running out, she would like to get fresh supplies and is thus requesting a loan from WAGES to purchase jewelry of varying quality in order to increase her income and satisfy her customers' needs.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of jewelry

loans.name: Katatei  Ene

texts.en:
Katatei Ene K., 36 years old, is married to Leposo K. and a mother of three children. Katatei is a farmer; she has been farming her own piece of land for the last 13 years.

She learned about KADET from other women nearby who are already registered members in KADET. This will be her first loan. She is planning to spend 30000 KES to plant more maize, which normally does well in her area due to good climatic conditions.

She hopes to use the profit from the proceeds of this loan to expand her farming activity from small scale to commercial farming. Katatei's dream is to do large scale farming and attain financial independence.

She is a hard working woman who is determined to achieve her set goals.

loans.use: To prepare her land to plant more maize.

loans.name: Amélé

texts.fr: mariée et mère de 3 enfants, V.  a ouvert sa propre boutique de vente de produits d'alimentation générale, elle fait ce commerce il y a de cela 6 ans. ce commerce lui réussit et elle réalise de bonnes recettes. actuellement son stock de marchandises s'épuise alors que la demande de ses clients ne cesse d'augmenter. pour les satisfaire, elle doit se réapprovisionner. elle demande à WAGES un crédit pour acheter 3 cartons de sucres, 4 cartons de tomates en boîte de conserves, 3 sacs de riz GINO et divers autres produits d'alimentation générale.
texts.en:
Married and mother to three children, Mrs. V. has opened her own general grocery store. She has had this business for six years now and it is successful, making her a good income. Currently her stock of goods is running out, while at the same time customer demand is constantly increasing. In order to satisfy her customers, she needs to get fresh supplies. She is asking for a loan from WAGES to buy three cartons of sugar, four catrons of tinned tomatoes, three sacks or Gino rice and various other food products.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of general food products

loans.name: Muntorosi Ole

texts.en:
Muntorosi Ole P., 28-years-old, is married to Tipaya P. and they have three children. Muntorosi is a farmer; he has farmed his own piece of land for the last 8 years.

He learned about KADET from marketing awareness done by KADET staff in his area. This will be his first loan. He is planning to use it for maize farming; maize has proved to do very well due to fertile land in the area along with adequate rainfall.

With the profits he hopes to make from the proceeds of this loan he plans to buy more land to farm and increase his maize production. He also hopes to buy some livestock and start livestock farming.

His future dream is that he will be able to practice large scale maize farming. He is a hardworking man who is determined to achieve his set goals and dreams.

loans.use: To prepare land for maize planting.

loans.name: Sadiatou

texts.fr: il y a plus de 10 ans que cette femme s'est spécialisée dans le commerce de tissus et de bazins, elle maîtrise parfaitement ce marché. elle fait ce commerce de façon ambulante pour toucher plus de clients; elle s'approvisionne au burkina faso, un pays voisin  et à lomé. le stock actuel de marchandises ne lui permet pas de subvenir aux besoins de ses clients. elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour l'achat de divers tissus et divers bazins de différentes qualités. elle est mariée et mère de 5 enfants
texts.en:
For over ten years, Mrs. K. Y. has been a specialized dealer of fabrics and Guinea brocade (bazin); she is now a master of this trade. She sells door to door in order to reach more clients. She buys her cloth in Burkina Faso, a neighboring country, and in Lomé. Her current stock of fabrics is not enough to meet the needs of her clients, so she is asking for a loan from WAGES to buy assorted fabrics and bazins of various quality. She is married and is the mother of 5 children.

Translated from French by Eileen Jessop, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fabrics and Guinea Brocade

loans.name: For Help Group

texts.en:
Meet with the members of the “For Help” group from Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. They have come to SMT, a Kiva partner, to apply for a loan of SLL 500,000 each in order to help them develop their businesses.

The leader of the group, Isatu K. (pictured in the left), is 27 years old. She is married with two children.

Isatu sells cosmetics, clothes, jewelry, toothpaste, etc., and has been doing this business for many years now. With her share of this loan, she will buy more of the above-mentioned items in large quantity to add to her stock.

loans.use: To buy more cosmetics, clothes, jewelry, toothpaste, etc.

loans.name: Amintou

texts.fr: cette  femme dispose d'une boutique dans laquelle elle exerce le commerce de produits d'alimentation générale; elle fait ce commerce depuis 4 ans déjà.  elle veut gonfler son stock pour accroître son Chiffre d'Affaire, elle demande à WAGES son premier crédit afin de s'acheter de confuseries, 4 cartons de détergents OMO, 7 boîtes de lait PEAK, 5 paniers moyens de tomates et divers autres produits alimentaires.elle est mariée et mère d'un enfant.
texts.en:
This woman runs a shop where she has been selling general food products for four years. In order to increase her stocks and boost her profits, she is requesting her first loan from WAGES to buy sweets, 4 boxes of OMO detergent, 7 cartons of PEAK milk, 5 medium-sized baskets of tomatoes and various other food items. She is married and has one child.

Translated from French by Nathalie Pelletier, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase general food products

loans.name: Mussarat Nazir's Group

texts.en:
Mussarat Nazir, 53 years old, lives in the historic city of Lahore, in Pakistan. She makes her livelihood from her clothes-sewing business. She sews clothes for her neighborhood clients. She is also involved in selling clothes.

She purchases cloth from the Azam market, a big cloth market in Lahore. She generates better income with her clothes selling business than from her sewing but she can't quit her sewing because her customers don't allow her to quit because of the quality of her stitching.

Her husband, M. A., is a driver. He works full-time to put three meals on the table for his family. They have three sons who could not complete their education due to financial constraints. They all are young now and involved in different kinds of work. The eldest and youngest son are rickshaw drivers and the middle son has a business of renting bikes.

Mussarat has applied for her third loan from Asasah for her clothes selling business. With the loan she will buy clothes in bulk and expand her business.

She has applied for a loan for this business because she has been doing it for the last 15 years and she is very sure that she can change the fortune of her family by expanding this business. She is a regular borrower from Asasah and has maintained a good credit record in the last two years.

loans.use: To purchase clothes to resell.

loans.name: Mikael Parkuyiare

texts.en:
Mikael Parkuyiare N. is 23 years old, single and, for the last three years, has made a living as a farmer.  He lives in a fertile region which is well-known for producing large wheat crops. 

He learned about KADET through a marketing campaign conducted by our organization in his area. He is applying for his first loan, which he will use to buy pesticides to protect his crop from pests. He hopes to use the additional profit made possible by this loan to acquire more land for his farm. This will allow him to meet a rapidly-growing demand for wheat. 

His hope and dream is to become a large-scale farmer and own farm machinery.

Mikael is a young and energetic man who can do more if he receives financial help.

loans.use: To buy pestsides for his wheat farm.

loans.name: Jazgul

texts.en:
Jazgul A. lives in Balykchi, a small city near Lake Isykul. She is 33 years old, married and has a three-year-old daughter. Her husband is employed as a policeman and earns 10000 soms per month. Jazgul makes a living as an operator with the local fire department where she earns 7,000 soms a month. In her free time, she supplements this income by selling women’s clothes in a local market. She opened this business a year ago with a small investment of 4,000 soms and now earns more than 12,000 soms a month. Her profits allowed her to buy a car for 70,000 soms. Jazgul has applied for this loan to expand her business by buying school uniforms that she can sell when the new school year starts. In the future, her dream is to buy her own flat, and save enough money to give her daughter a good education. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 

MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds these principles – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (being environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning enough revenue to expand independently). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to buy school uniforms to sell to her customers

loans.name: Ablavi

texts.fr: M. ablavi est une dame  très dynamique. elle vit avec son époux et ses enfants dans le quartier de hedzranawoé. elle exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de charbons de bois, elle fait ce commerce depuis 2005 et s'approvisionne dans les marchés locaux de Lomé. son stock de charbons de bois est épuisée, elle souhaite se réapprovisionner très rapidement pour pouvoir satisfaire ses clients; elle sollicite donc son premier crédit de WAGES pour l'achat de 20 sacs de charbons de bois.
texts.en:
Ablavi M. is a very energetic woman. She lives with her husband and children in the Hedzranawoé district. Her line of business is selling charcoal. She has operated this business since 2005 and obtains her supplies in Lomé’s local markets. Her supply of charcoal is exhausted and she would like to stock up very quickly so that she can satisfy her customers. Therefore, she is asking for her first loan from WAGES to buy 20 bags of charcoal.

Translated from French by Connie Archea, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy charcoal

loans.name: David Nterere

texts.en:
David Nterere K. is 30 years old, married to Nayioloang Enole K. and supports four members of his family by working as a farmer. He owns a plot of land and has worked on it for more than three years. 

He learned about KADET from a friend who is a member. He is applying for his first loan, which he will use to buy pesticides to spray on his wheat crop, buy seeds and take other steps to improve his farm's output. 

He hopes to use the revenue made possible by this loan to expand his farm and begin moving into large-scale commercial farming. His long-term goals are to attain financial independence and improve his family's living standards.

David is a hardworking young man who is determined to achieve his goals.

loans.use: to buy seeds and pesticide, and take other steps to improve his farm's output

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva lender is a 33-year-old Lebanese man who is married and has two young children. He is the sole provider for his family and has worked as a farmer for the last eight years. Since 2008, he has managed his own farm, where he grows fruits and vegetables. Occasionally, he encloses portions of his crops in plastic tents to increase his farm's output and market his produce in nearby towns and cities over a longer growing season. He is applying for a loan for $1,200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to buy seeds and other items for his farm. He estimates that this loan will help him increase his profits by 15 percent.

Note: Because of political and social concerns in Lebanon, we have made this application anonymous to protect the borrower (i.e., blacking out portions of the photo and not supplying names and locations.) Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these issues and encourages lenders to continue their support for borrowers in Lebanon.

About Ameen:
Ameen s.a.l. has been a major player in the Lebanese Microfinance sector since 1999. Originally, a micro-credit program created by CHF International, Ameen became Ameen s.a.l. in 2003,. In 2007, Ameen s.a.l. registered with the Central Bank of Lebanon to become the first Lebanese financial institution that specializes in miicrofinance.

At Ameen s.a.l., we pledge to provide financial services to the largest number of micro- and small entrepreneurs and working poor, in order to help them develop their businesses and improve their incomes.

Ameen has been able to use its interest-free loans Kiva to offer lower-interest loans with faster disbursement to borrowers. Since its inception, Ameen has provided high-quality financial services to over 41,000 borrowers and disbursed over 81,000 loans worth $115 million. To learn more about Ameen, please visit http://partners.kiva.org/partners/115

loans.use: to buy supplies for a farm

loans.name: Temitha Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are the members of the “Temitha” group from Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. They are petty-business people who have come to SMT, a Kiva partner, to apply for a loan of SLL 500,000 each to help them develop their businesses.

Sento T. is the leader of the group and she is pictured on the left. Sento is a 30-year-old woman who is married with four children: two in secondary school and two not of school-going age.

Sento sells foofoo (food made from cassava), groundnuts (peanuts), rubber bowls, etc. She will use her share of the loan to buy more of the above-mentioned items in large quantities to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more foofoo, groundnuts, rubber bowls, etc., to sell

loans.name: Moses Sankale

texts.en:
Moses Sankale O. is 29 years old and supports four people in his family.

Moses is a farmer and he does the farming on his own piece of land, which he has been doing for the last three years.

He learned about KADET through a friend who is already a registered member of KADET microfinance.This will be his first loan. He is planning to spend 15,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) to plow, 10,000 KES on harrowing,15,000 KES on seeds and 10,000 KES on planting his 5 acres of wheat.

He hopes to use the profit from the proceeds of this loan to expand his farming activity from small-scale to commercial farming.

Moses' dream is do large-scale farming, attain financial independence and buy his own farm machinery. He is hardworking and determined to achieve his dream.

loans.use: To plow, harrow, and plant with seeds 5 acres of wheat

loans.name: Katampe Maraswa

texts.en:
Katampe has practiced livestock farming for eight years. He is 27 years old and married to Saitet N.. They have two children.

He was introduced to KADET by a friend and has no history with any other MFI (microfinance institution). This will be his first loan with KADET. He plans to use the cash to buy more calves, which he will rear and sell at a profit later, after they grow.

Katampe also plans to open a butchery in the near future.

loans.use: To buy more calves, which he will sell later

loans.name: Malal Mara Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are the members of the “Malal Mara” group. They are small-scale-business women who are based in Magburaka, a town in northern Sierra Leone. They are seeking a loan of SLL 600,000 each to enable them to further expand their businesses. Consequently, they will make more profit and improve their standard of living.

The leader of this group is Aminata B. K.. Aminata was born in a village called Malal Mara, one of the villages surrounding Magburaka town, and is approximately age thirty-nine. She is married with two children. Her husband is a businessman and one of her children is in primary school and the other is in college.

Aminata has been a businesswoman for seventeen years now. She sells rice, gari (fast food made from cassava), palm-oil (the country’s favorite cooking oil), and soap. With this loan, she will expand her business by buying more rice, gari and palm-oil in large quantity.

loans.use: To buy more rice, gari and palm-oil in large quantity

loans.name: Leulele Ole

texts.en:
Leulele has been rearing animals for sale in Naivasha town for 20 years. He is 44 years old and married to Maite K.. They have three children.

He was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his first loan. He plans to use the income that he gets after the business has expanded to  improve his standard of living and, at the same time, to sustain the business.

He hopes to grow this animal-rearing business to large-scale farming, in that he will be able to supply the entire Naivasha town with animals for sale.

loans.use: To add more sheep and goats to his stock

loans.name: Kayainktheke Group

texts.en:
Issa Banard T. (pictured on the left) is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs. Issa was born in Magburaka, a town in northern Sierra Leone. Thirty-eight-year-old Issa is married to a businesswoman and they have four children. Two of Issa’s children are attending secondary school and two are in primary school. 

For seven years now, Issa has been selling medicines and cosmetics. With the help of this loan, he and his group members will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve their living conditions. Issa will use his share of the loan (SLL 400,000) to buy more medicines and cosmetics to add to his pharmacy.

loans.use: To buy more medicines and cosmetics to add to his pharmacy

loans.name: Geoffrey Keroket

texts.en:
Geoffrey has been practicing mixed farming in Naivasha town for the last 30 years. He plants maize and also rears animals, which he sells later at a profit.  He is 58 years old and has three children.

He was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his first loan. He plans to buy livestock, which he will rear and sell later.

Geoffrey plans to buy another piece of land for planting, which he believes will increase his output.

loans.use: To buy livestock, which he will rear and sell later

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more bags of used clothes

loans.name: Evans Omwenyi

texts.en:
Evans Omwenyi N. is 36 years old. He is married to Dorcas Kemunto omwenyi and a father of four children. Evans is a carpenter and he does his business in the middle of a busy residential estate in Narok town,  he has been doing this work for the last ten years.

He learned about KADET from other members in a group already registered with KADET in his area of residence. This will be his first loan which he is planning to spend on buying more materials to expand his business to meet the demand for furniture. With the anticipated profit from his expanded business he is planning to open up a new work shop on another street in the town.

Evans hope and dream is that he will be able to buy his own piece of land and build a good living house. He also hopes to buy a vehicle totransport raw materials like timber, seat covers and others from the suppliers direct without relying on middlemen.

He is a hard working man and determined to achieve his goals.

loans.use: To buy more timber and seat covers to meet the demand for modern seats.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more cloth.

loans.name: Beugueu Diam Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité BEUGUEU JAM  est créé depuis plus de 08 ans. Il est composé de 08 femmes issues du même village. Elles ont formé leur groupe par affinité et par voisinage. Le groupe fait partie du Banc Villageois de SANGHE DOUKA.

Madame Adama P. deuxième à partir de la droite de la photo (mise en médaillon) est responsable du groupe. Elle est âgée de 52 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de 5 enfants. 

Elle vend des céréales locales (mil et maïs) elle vend également des arachides. Elle pratique cette activité depuis plus de 10 ans.

Avec son crédit elle va augmenter son niveau d’approvisionnement en marchandises pour mieux satisfaire sa clientèle et générer plus de bénéfices. 

Son objectif est de soutenir son mari dans la prise en charge financière de la famille
texts.en:
The solidarity group BEUGUEU JAM was formed more than 8 years ago. It is composed of 8 women from the same village. They formed their group by neighborhood and kinship. The group is affiliated with the SANGHE DOUKA village bank. Mrs. Adama P., second on the right in the photo (seen in the medaillon), is the leader of the group. She is 52 years old, married and the mother of 5 children. She sells local grains (millet and corn) and also sells peanuts. She has operated this business for more than 10 years. With her loan she is going to increase her stock of merchandise so that she can better satisfy her customers and generate more profit. Her goal is to help her husband provide for the family’s financial needs.

Translated from French by Connie Archea, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy local grains

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more cartons of soap, candle, matches, sardine, milk, sugar, soft drink, batteries etc

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more bags of used shoes.

loans.name: Mareme

texts.fr: Madame Maréme C. est une commerçante âgée de plus de 50 ans et mére de famille qui vit dans la communauté rurale de Sandiara à une vingtaine de kilomètres de Mbour .Son activité commerciale réside dans la vente de prêt à porter au niveau de Sandiara .Ainsi, pour accroitre son fonds de commerce et agmenter sa rentabilité elle sollicite un crédit au niveau de la caisse. Elle gére seule le fonctionnement de la famille et s'occupe de la ration alimentaire
texts.en:
Mrs. Maréme C., over 50 years old, is a mother and entrepreneur living in the rural community of Sandiara, about 20 km from Mbour. Her line of business is selling ready-to-wear clothing in Sandiara. In order to bolster her business capital and increase profitability, she is seeking a loan. She manages the family budget on her own, and it is she who takes care of providing food for the family.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business use

loans.name: Kipetuan Ole

texts.en:
Kipetuan has been rearing cattle to sell in Naivasha town for the last fifteen years. He is 50 years old, is married to Julia Kipetuan, and they have three children.

Kipetuan was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his first loan. He plans to buy more calves which he will add to his stock and sell them later at a profit.

Kipetuan hopes to grow into real estate in the future, building rental houses in Naivasha.

loans.use: To buy more calves to add to his stock

loans.name: Latyr

texts.fr: Monsieur Latyr F. est un éleveur qui effectue des activités d'embouche au niveau de Sandiara.issu d'une ethnie sérére qui ont la même particularité que les peulh nomade de cette localité ,Mr F. est un habitué de ce secteur et vient solliciter à nouveau un crédit pour acheter des moutons pour la prévision de la fête de tabaski qui aura lieu dans prés de 3 mois . A cet effet Mr F. pourra revendre son produit à bon prix et en profiter pour régler ses dépenses annuelles car en priode de l'hivernage le paturage se fait rare pour le betail et les greniers sont vides
texts.en:
Mr. Latyr F. is a farmer who raises livestock in Sandiara. He belongs to the Sérére ethnic group, related to the nomadic ethnic group of Peulh in the same region. Mr. F. is an experienced farmer; he is requesting a new loan in order to purchase sheep, in the anticipation of the Tabaski [Eid] festival about three months from now. On this occasion, Mr. F. could resell the sheep at a good price and take advantage of it to provide for his annual expenses, since during the winter season there are hardly any pastures available for the animals, and the haylofts are empty.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing sheep

loans.name: Tiampati Ole

texts.en:
Tiampati has practiced livestock farming for the last four years and finds the venture very profitable. He is 25 years old, is married to Sisian Ene Nisa, and they have three children.

Tiampati was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his first loan. He plans to use the money to buy more cattle which he will rear and sell later at a profit.

Tiampati hopes to expand his business,and improve his standard of living.

loans.use: To buy more cattle to raise and sell

loans.name: Stand Strong Group

texts.en:
These women are the members of the “Stand Strong United” group. They are small-scale-business women in Magburaka, a town in northern Sierra Leone, and this will be their first loan from SMT/Kiva.

With the help of this loan, these entrepreneurs will be able to expand their businesses and make more sales and better profits. Consequently, their living standards will improve and they will be able to at least provide three meals a day for their children, pay their schools fees, buy them clothes to wear, and pay their medical bills if any of them fall sick.

Mahawa K. is the leader of this group. She was born in Magburaka town. She is married to a teacher and they have five children: three in primary school, one in secondary school, and one not of school-going age.

Mahawa sells ready-to-wear clothes and has been running this business for many years now. With her share of this loan, she will buy dozens of ready-to-wear clothes to add to her stock.

loans.use: To buy dozens of ready-to-wear clothes to add to her stock

loans.name: Hellen

texts.en:
Hellen H. is currently in the business of selling foodstuffs at her restaurant and is requesting a loan to stock more foodstuffs to cook and sell. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to extend the floor of her restaurant.

Hellen is 31 years old and is married to a driver. She has two children and her children go to school.

loans.use: To stock more foodstuffs to cook and sell in the her restaurant

loans.name: Luz Maria

texts.es:
Hace 12 años Luz María M. Benítez se vino  desde el Carmen de Bolívar, con su conyugue y sus tres hijos a Barranquilla buscando paz y estabilidad en los ingresos; ellos llegaron  inicialmente donde un pariente que les tendió la mano y cuando posteriormente su esposo consiguió un trabajo de celador  en un remolcador donde se mudaron, logrando que después de un tiempo el propietario de este,  le cediera una pieza donde  ampliaron gradualmente  e iniciaron su negocio de criar animales y vender su carne;  hoy se dedican a ello y matan 60 cerdos , actividad  de la que se encarga  Luz María,  mientras su esposo trabaja en un astillero, lugar donde ella  consiguió el negocio de vender  almuerzos a un promedio de 35 empleados diariamente  y cada día adquiere mayores proporciones en cuanto a sus clientes se refiere . Este es su cuarto crédito con la Fundación y solicita su credikiva por valor de $1.000.000 COP,  para comprar cerdos para la cría, engorde y venta de su carne y también,  adquirir en mayor volumen materias primas e insumos, para la preparación de los almuerzos que vende.
Con sus créditos ha conseguido aumentar sus utilidades y con ello comprar un carro que utiliza  para  el negocio. Su sueño ahora está enfocado en comprar una casa y este es su gran desafío el ahorro constante para hacerlo, pero ella ya aprendió a solucionar sus desafíos, desde que llegó a Barranquilla solo con deseos de salir adelante,  impulsada por ofrecerles seguridad y un mejor bienestar a sus hijos, que entonces eran pequeños y en la actualidad están estudiando y ya organizados.
texts.en:
Twelve years ago Luz María M. Benítez came from El Carmen de Bolívar to Barranquilla with her spouse and three children seeking peace and economic stability. At first they arrived at a relative’s who helped them out. Later, when her husband got a job as a watchman at a towing site, they moved. In time, her husband’s boss gave them a room that they gradually enlarged and they started their business of raising animals to sell their meat. Today, they are in this line of work and they butcher 60 pigs. Luz María is in charge of this particular task while her husband works at a saw mill where she secured the business of preparing daily lunches there for 35 employees and daily her business grows. This is the 4th loan with the Foundation and she’s asking for a Kiva loan in the amount of $1.000.000 COP to buy pigs to raise for subsequent pork sales as well as to acquire larger amounts of raw materials and ingredients to prepare the lunches she sells. The loans have made it possible for her to increase profits and buy a car that she uses in the business. Her dream is focused on buying a house and this is the great challenge she faces: the constant need to save in order to reach it. However, she learned how to overcome her challenges since she arrived in Barranquilla with only the wish to get ahead, pushed by the need to provide security and wellbeing for her children who were then little. Currently, they are studying and well organized.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy pigs to raise in order to sell pork and to acquire larger amounts of ingredients and raw ingredients for the lunches she sells.

loans.name: Love Group

texts.en:
Siah G., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called Love. Siah is 32 years old, married, and has two children who range from 5 to 11 years old. She was not able to attend school due to lack of financial support. She cares for one sibling.

For 16 years, she has been selling soap, perfume, candles, door locks, body lotion, and other mixed goods in Rally Time Market in Monrovia, Liberia. She plans to use her 9,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 45,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy more cartons of soap, perfume, candles, door locks, body lotion, and other mixed goods.

 She describes herself as a respectful woman. Her dream is to grow her business and build a house.

loans.use: To buy more products to sell

loans.name: Matham Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are the members of the “Matham” group. They are small-scale-business women based in Magburaka, a town in northern Sierra Leone. They are seeking a loan of SLL 3,100,000 to enable them to further expand their businesses. Consequently, they will make more profits and improve on their standard of living.

The leader of this group is Ramatu S., age fifty, who was born in Matham village. Her husband is a businessman and, currently, Ramatu, her husband and five children reside in Magburaka town. One of her children is attending secondary school and the rest are now grown-ups.

Ramatu has been selling cigarettes, pepper, Margi (used to give sauces a sweet taste), firewood, etc., for many years now. With this loan, she will be able to expand her business by buying more firewood, pepper, Margi, cigarettes, etc., in large quantity.

loans.use: To buy firewood, pepper, Margi, cigarettes, etc., in large quantity

loans.name: Cheikh

texts.fr: Monsieur Chiekh F. es un jeune qui s'active dans l'élevage de poulets de chairs dans la localité de Sandiara Mr F. posséde un grand poulaillé qui peut abriter prés de 500 poussins .Pour les besoins de la fête de korité qui correspond à la fin du Ramadan (le jeûn)Cheikh F. sollicite un crédit pour renforcer ses sujets pour faire face à une éventuelle demande de sa clientèle et des villages environnant. C'est grace à ce poulaillé que Mr F. fait vivre sa famille et s'occuper  de ses enfants
texts.en:
Mr. Cheikh F. is a young man active in the chicken farming business in Sandiara. Mr. F. has a large chicken coop that can contain up to 500 chicks. When considering the impact of the Korite festivities (which corresponds to the ending of Ramadan), young Cheikh F. is requesting a loan to bolster his number of chickens to meet a potential increase in demand from his customers and from neighbouring villages. This chicken coop is what enables Mr. F. to feed his family and take care of his children.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: poultry farming

loans.name: No Joke Group

texts.en:
These women are small-scale-business people in Magburaka, a town in northern Sierra Leone. They have come to SMT, a Kiva partner, to seek a loan of SLL 500,000 each to enable them expand their businesses.

With a loan of SLL 500,000, they will each be able to add more stock to their business and make more sales and more profit. Consequently, they will be able to improve their standard of living by sending their children to school and by feeding and clothing them.

Kadiatu T. is the leader of this group. She was born in Magburaka, thirty-five years ago. She is married to a businessman and has three children, all attending schools: one in primary school and two in secondary school.

Kadiatu sells eggs and bottled water which she has been doing for many years now. With her share of the loan, she will expand her business by buying more eggs, plastic bags and palm-oil (the most popular cooking oil).

loans.use: To buy eggs, plastic bags and palm-oil to sell

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 46-year-old married man from Lebanon who has two young children. He has been working as a builder specializing in gypsum board for almost twenty years and is the main income provider for his wife and children. He has been running his own business since 2000, working on a freelance basis upon request of his clients. His work has developed well over the years and his business income has increased. Today, he is requesting a loan of $1,200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase additional wood for his construction work. He estimates that the loan will help him increase his profits during the summer season. Note: Based on the political and social challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (e.g. blanking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, not indicating his/her name and location, etc.). Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Lebanon's borrowers. About Ameen: Ameen s.a.l. has been a major player in the Lebanese micro-finance sector since 1999. Originally, a micro-credit program created by CHF International, Ameen evolved to become Ameen s.a.l. in 2003, a Lebanese services company. In 2007, Ameen s.a.l. registered with the Central Bank of Lebanon to become the first Lebanese financial institution specialized in micro-finance. At Ameen s.a.l. we pledge to provide financial services to the largest number of micro and small entrepreneurs and to the working poor, to help them develop their businesses and improve their incomes. Ameen has been able to use its interest-free loan from Kiva to offer lower interest loans with faster disbursement to its micro-loan borrowers. Since its inception, Ameen has provided high quality financial services to over 41,000 borrowers and disbursed over 81,000 loans totaling US$115 million. To learn more about Ameen, please click here.

loans.use: To purchase additional wood for his construction work

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary P. is currently in the business of selling maize flour, rice and cassava flour at the market and is requesting a loan to stock bags of beans and pulses (e.g. groundnuts, peas, cowpeas) to sell.

Mary is 29 years old and is married to a teacher. She has two children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a shop for her goods.

loans.use: To stock bags of beans and pulses to sell

loans.name: Luz Marina

texts.es:
Luz Marina S. está muy feliz con su hija, ya que logró terminar su semestre sin contratiempos, porque se preparó, estudió mucho y pasó al otro nivel de Contaduría pública en la Universidad.  Últimamente  Luz Marina se acercó a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo para solicitar otro  credikiva  y pagar la matricula del nuevo   semestre  de Contaduría publica que iniciará su hija; con el credikiva semestral cuenta  hasta el final de su carrera, pues es una  oportunidad para tener resuelto la matricula de semestre a semestre, hasta que ella  logre ser profesional.
Si usted quiere conocer la historia de Luz Marina siga a continuacion el enlace: 
 http://partners.kiva.org/lend/173039
texts.en:
Luz Marina S. is very proud of her daughter, who was able to finish her semester without any setbacks. By preparing herself and studying hard, she was able to pass to the next level in her university studies in the area of Public Accounting. Recently, Luz Marina came to the Mario Santo Domingo Foundation to request another Kiva loan to pay the matriculation fees for her daughter's new semester in Public Accounting. She will have this semi-annual loan until the end of her course of study; it is an opportunity to have her matriculation covered from semester to semester until she earns her professional degree. If you would like to know more about Luz Marina's history, visit the following link: http://partners.kiva.org/lend/173039 .

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Paying for her daughter's university semester

loans.name: Elsie De Dios

texts.es:
Elsie O. A.  siempre está haciendo algo productivo, porque pasa de una actividad a otra con facilidad y es que esto es  parte de su rutina diaria; ella  tiene varios negocios: un café internet, donde ofrece servicios de telecomunicaciones, impresiones, fotocopiaje y también alquila lavadoras, tiene una vitrina donde vende mercancías  y  como si fuera poco elabora fritos, chuzos, deditos, empanaditas  y  también prepara los más deliciosos helados de frutas de su barrio, ubicado en un sitio cercano a la Playa.

Últimamente 2 de sus lavadoras, están funcionando mal y necesita repararlas y  también requiere cambiar las mesas de su café internet, pero igualmente tiene que  prepararse para tener inventarios de mercancías renovadas para ofrecerlas, especialmente el día del amor y de la amistad que ya se acerca, por eso acude a su credikiva por valor de $2.000.000 COP para lograrlo.

Su carrera emprendedora inició hace 10 años, cuando en una comunidad religiosa una hermana de la caridad,  directora de un colegio, le propuso organizar un grupo asociativo, para elaborar conservas en el Corregimiento la Playa, así fuè como con otras vecinas  se prepararon técnicamente para aprender a elaborarlas y también acudieron a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo para recibir  asesoría técnica   en la estandarización de los productos y diversificación de los mismos y se prepararon administrativamente en el manejo del negocio , para finalmente acceder a créditos , este negocio fuè muy bueno; pero a Elsie el calor la dejó con muchos quebrantos de salud y debió abandonar esta actividad y dedicarse a buscar otras alternativas, así fuè como 5 años después en su propia casa preparaba conservas y helados y tres años después solicitó crédito individual a la Fundación , para comprar las lavadoras y mediante su trabajo y 6 créditos  ha ido adecuando un local de su vivienda y agregando otros servicios como el del café internet que ya tiene 2 computadores más y genera no solo su propio forma de trabajo , sino también la de una sobrina y su esposo, este último la apoya en el transporte de las lavadoras, pues el independientemente realiza una actividad muy estacionaria y la mayor parte del tiempo debe esperar a que le salga trabajo.

Elsie tiene dos hijos y uno de ellos es ingeniero de sistemas y el otro estudia  para ser  técnico de cocina. Ella afirma que su familia es muy unida y por eso con trabajo y grandes esfuerzos han salido adelante, pero aún recuerda el primer impulso que le hizo Sor Olì , la hermanita de la iglesia, quien gestionó el que ella estuviera vinculada a la Fundación y esto  lo agradece mucho.

Su meta ahora es legalizar su negocio y ampliarlo pero tiene el desafío  del  encontrar un operador de internet que le ofrezca un mejor servicio que el actual. En la foto, Elsie sale en su café internet.
texts.en:
Elsie O. A. is always busy doing something productive, because she moves easily from one activity to another, and this is part of her daily routine. She has several businesses: she runs an Internet café, where she offers telecommunications services and also rents washing machines; she has a display case where she sells merchandise; and if that weren't enough, she prepares fried foods, skewers, "fingers" and little empanadas, and she also makes the most delicious fruit-flavored ice creams in her neighborhood, which is located near La Playa. Recently, two of her washing machines have been malfunctioning. She needs to repair them, and she also needs to replace the tables in her Internet café. However, at the same time, she needs to prepare herself with enough new merchandise to sell, especially for Valentine's Day and Friendship Day, which is coming up soon. For this reason, she is requesting a Kiva loan in the amount of 2,000,000 COP to achieve this. Her entrepreneurial career began 10 years ago, when a Sister of Charity in a religious community, the director of a school, suggested that she organize an associative group to prepare preserved food in the township of La Playa. Thus, with other neighbors, she received technical training in food preparation and also came to the Mario Santo Domingo Foundation for technical advice in standardizing and diversifying their products. They also learned how to manage their business administratively, in order to gain access to loans. This business went very well, but Elsie found that the heat caused her many health problems, and she had to abandon this work and look for other alternatives. Thus, some 5 years later, she was preparing preserved foods and ice cream in her own home, and three years after that, she applied for an individual loan from the Foundation to buy washing machines. Through her work and with the help of 6 loans, she has been able to set up a shop in her home and has added other services such as the Internet café, which now has 2 more computers and generates work not only for Elsie herself, but also for a niece and her husband. The latter helps her with the transportation of the washing machines, because he works independently in a field that is highly seasonal, and much of the time he has to wait around for opportunities to work. Elsie has two sons; one is a systems engineer, and the other is studying to become a culinary technician. She affirms that her family is very united, and because of this, with hard work and great efforts, they have been able to get ahead. However, she still remembers the first impetus given to her by Sister Olì, the nun at the church, who brought her into contact with the Foundation, and she appreciates this very much. Her goal now is to officially register her business and expand it, but she is currently facing the challenge of finding an Internet provider that offers her better service than her current one. Elsie is pictured in her Internet cafe.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Repairing 2 washing machines and buying tables for her Internet café and merchandise to stock her display case for Valentine's and Friendship Days

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose J. is currently in the business of selling bread and tomatoes at the market and is requesting a loan to stock fresh fish to fry and sell.

Rose is 42 years old and is married to a carpenter. She has four children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a restaurant.

loans.use: To stock fresh fish to fry and sell

loans.name: Kani

texts.en:
Kani S. is currently in the business of selling beans, pulses (e.g. groundnuts, peas, cowpeas) and dried fish and is requesting a loan to stock tomatoes to sell.

Kani is 39 years old and is married to a peasant. She has three children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a shop.

loans.use: To stock tomatoes to sell

loans.name: Keswe Ole

texts.en:
Keswe is a farmer who has been rearing livestock to sell for four years. He is 28 years old, is married to Sisina Ene Keswe, and they have three children.

Keswe was introduced to KADET by his friend and has no history with any other MFI. This will be his first loan. He plans to use the money to buy more cattle to add to his stock for later sale.

Keswe also plans to open a butcher shop in future.

loans.use: To buy more cattle which he will sell later

loans.name: Daouda

texts.fr: Monsieur Daouda F. est un jeune qui vie à quelques kilomètres de Sandiara à Sesséne Diaraw qui effectué du transport par le biais de sa charette également Mr F. pour le compte des populations bénéficiaires . Egalement Mr F. voudrais se lancer dans l'embouche pour l'achat de bétails qui sera élevé et revendu dans le marché hebdomadaire de Sandiara . Ainsi Mr F. demande un crédit pour réaliser son nouveau projet qui lui permettra de générer des revenus et faire face à ses  besoins quotidiens et ceux de sa famille
texts.en:
Mr. Daouda F. is a young man living in Sessene Diaraw, a few kilometers from Sandiara, who uses a cart to transport goods as a service to the local population. He also would like to start a cattle-fattening business: buying, raising and reselling cattle at the weekly Sandiara market. Therefore Mr. F. is requesting a credit loan to finance his new project which will generate revenue so that he can meet his daily needs and those of his family.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Embouche

loans.name: Takku Ligueye Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité TAKKU LIGGUEYE est créé depuis plus de 12 ans. Il est composé de 08 femmes issues du même village. Elles ont formé leur groupe par affinité et par voisinage. Le groupe fait partie du Banc Villageois de SANGHE DOUKA.

Astou S. en troisième position à partir de la droite sur la photo et mise en médaillon est responsable du groupe. Elle est âgée de 55 ans. Elle est mariée et mère 07 enfants et tutrice de deux autres enfants. 

Elle fait un petit commerce de tissus et de vaisselles. Elle mène cette activité depuis plus d’une décennie. 

Son crédit lui permet d’acheter plus de pièces de tissus et des vaisselles pour augmenter son chiffre d’affaire 
Elle a pu à partir de ses bénéfices acheter une parcelle à titre d’habitation et son objectif à long terme est de construire une maison.
texts.en:
The Takku Liggueye solidarity group was created over 12 years ago. It consists of eight women from the same village. They came together through personal affinities and as neighbours. The group is part of the Sanghe Douka “Banc Villageois” loan association. Astou S. –the group leader- is third from the right in the picture and is portrayed in the medallion. She is 55 years old, married, the mother of seven children and tutor of two other children. She has been running a small business retailing clothing fabric and tableware for over a decade. Her credit loan enabled her to buy more pieces of fabric and tableware to increase her turnover. Her earnings enabled her to buy a plot of land where she intends to build a home in the long term.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: BUy clothing fabric and tableware

loans.name: Aujelia

texts.en:
Aujelia S. is currently in the business of selling charcoal from her home and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal to sell.

Aujelia is 31 years old and is married to a businessman. She has two children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: To stock more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Narcisa

texts.es:
La señora Narcisa A.  es casada, vive con su esposo y sus hijos  de 24, 21, 20, y 16 años en casa propia; los hijos mayores son independientes y viven en la zona Pasankeri sur de la ciudad de La Paz.
La señora Narcisa A. se dedica a tejer chompas y vender salchipapas y el esposo es albañil, así combinana ambas actividades para obtener sus ingresos para el hogar.
El crédito solicitado es para la construcción de y acabado de obra fina de una habitación donde ellos habitan y mejorar así su calidad de vida.
Es su cuarto crédito y el análisis socioeconómico realizado lo califica favorablemente y puede acceder  a un  crédito.
texts.en:
Sra. Narcisa A. is married and lives with her husband and children (ages 24, 21, 20, and 16) in her own home. Her adult children are independent and live in the Pasankeri District, which is in the southern portion of the city of La Paz. Sra. Narcisa weaves sweaters and sells “salchipapas” (sausages and fried potatoes), while her husband works as a mason. Both of their combined activities enable them to generate household income.

The loan she is requesting will be used to build and make the finishing touches on a room where they can spend time and improve their quality of life. This is her fourth loan and the socioeconomic analysis indicates she has a favorable rating, which qualifies her to access this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Finish the construction of a room and make the finishing touches

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 44-year-old married man from Lebanon. He is the father of two school-age children. He has owned his shop since 2000 where he sells beauty products, perfumes and gadgets. In addition to selling his products from his shop, he also works as a traveling salesman. His story illustrates, on a day-to-day basis, the challenges facing Lebanese fathers in trying to satisfy their families’ needs. They always try to find new opportunities to earn income. Today, he is requesting to borrow $1,200 to increase his store inventory to stock up before the coming holidays in Lebanon. During the holidays, his sales will increase and he needs to be prepared. He intends that his business productivity will grow as a result of the loan. Note: Based on the political and social challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (e.g. blanking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, not indicating his/her name and location, etc.). Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Lebanon's borrowers. About Ameen: Ameen s.a.l. has been a major player in the Lebanese micro-finance sector since 1999. Originally, a micro-credit program created by CHF International, Ameen evolved to become Ameen s.a.l. in 2003, a Lebanese services company. In 2007, Ameen s.a.l. registered with the Central Bank of Lebanon to become the first Lebanese financial institution specialized in micro-finance. At Ameen s.a.l. we pledge to provide financial services to the largest number of micro and small entrepreneurs and to the working poor, to help them develop their businesses and improve their incomes. Ameen has been able to use its interest-free loan from Kiva to offer lower interest loans with faster disbursement to its micro-loan borrowers. Since its inception, Ameen has provided high quality financial services to over 41,000 borrowers and disbursed over 81,000 loans totaling US$115 million. To learn more about Ameen, please click here.

loans.use: To increase his store inventory

loans.name: Juan

texts.es:
El señor Juan B. vive con su esposa e hijo de 10 años en casa propia en  la zona Alto Lojeta de la ciudad de La Paz.
El señor Juan B. trabaja como albañil por distintas zonas de los cuales obtiene sus ingresos para el hogar.
El crédito solicitado es para la construcción de una habitación para mejorar sus condiciones de vida.
Es su primer crédito y el análisis socioeconómico realizado lo califica favorablemente y puede acceder  a un  crédito.
texts.en:
Sr. Juan B. lives with his wife and ten year old son in their own house in the Alto Lojeta District of the city of La Paz. He works as a mason in different places to earn household income.

The loan he is requesting will be used to build a room to help improve his living conditions. This is first loan and the socioeconomic analysis indicates that he is qualified to access this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Construction of an additional room to his house

loans.name: Margret

texts.en:
Margret A. is currently in the business of selling local brew at her home and is requesting a loan to stock more brewing materials such as yeasts, etc.

Margret is 47 years old and is married to a peasant. She has five children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a small bar.

loans.use: To stock more brewing materials such as yeasts, etc.

loans.name: Jesus

texts.es:
El señor Jesús  es viudo; vive con sus hijos de 27, 25, 6 y 4 años  en  casa propia en la zona de Pasankeri sur de esta ciudad de La Paz. El señor Jesús es comerciante se dedica a la compra y venta de llamas es así como obtiene sus ingresos para el hogar.

El crédito solicitado es para la construcción de un muro posterior de su domicilio mejorando así su calidad de vida. Es su tercer crédito y el análisis socioeconómico realizado lo califica favorablemente y puede acceder  a un  crédito.
texts.en:
Sr. Jesús is a widower. He lives with his children (ages 27, 25, 6, and 4) in his own home in the district of Pasankeri, which is in the southern part of the city of La Paz.
