Ruth; ella tiene 39 años de edad y la socia es madre soltera y tiene 1 hijo; la socia alterna sus actividades del hogar con el comercio minorista; La socia  compra al por mayor y vende electrodomésticos desde hace 6 años, y repuestos también, La socia es una mujer muy emprendedora y viaja hasta Bolivia para poder obtener precios más cómodos y así tener mayor ganancia, La socia viaja cada 15 días, ella tiene sus proveedores y muchas veces le envían a ella los productos. La socia solicita el préstamo para hacer de este un capital para poder amortizar un primer pago.

La  socia valora y agradece el crédito otorgado ya que este le permite crecer y tener una mejor calidad de vida, así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
Ruth Q. belongs to the communal bank "REAL." She lives in the Santiago district of the province and department of Cusco. Ruth is 39 years old and is the single mother of a son. She alternates her activities in the house with her retail trade business. She has had a business buying household appliances at wholesale and then selling them for 6 years. She also sells spare parts for the appliances. She is a very enterprising woman who travels to Bolivia to get the best prices; this way her profits are better. She travels every 15 days. She has her suppliers, and many times they send her the products. Ruth is requesting a loan to use as capital to pay off a previous loan. Ruth values and appreciates the loan granted, since it will allow her to grow the business and have a better quality of life. She also pledges to make her payments according to the established time frame.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: she will use this loan to pay off a previous loan

loans.name: Juana

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal “REAL”; La socia vive en el distrito de Santiago en la provincia  y  departamento de Cusco.
	
La socia es la Sra. Juana; ella tiene 51 años de edad y la socia es conviviente y tiene 4 hijos; la socia alterna sus actividades con el comercio minorista; La socia  tiene solo secundaria incompleta, ella se dedico desde muy pequeña a trabajar porque en su hogar ya sus papas, no podían mantenerla, La socia ahora trabaja muy duro para que sus hijos tengan muy buena educación y puedan llegar a estudiar en la universidad para tener mejor futuro del que ella tuvo y mejores opciones de vida, La socia se dedica a vender zapatos en la provincia de Calca desde hace 1 año y le está yendo muy bien. La  socia solicita el préstamo para comprar zapatos al por mayor y continuar con sus negocio de venta de zapatos.

La  socia valora y agradece el crédito otorgado ya que este le permite crecer y tener una mejor calidad de vida, así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
This member belongs to the "REAL" village bank. She lives in the Santiago district in the department and province of Cusco. Her name is Juana. She's fifty-one-years-old, lives with her partner, and has four children. She alternates her daily activities with her retail business. She has only an incomplete secondary education. She started working when she was very small because her parents were not able to support her at home. Now she works very hard so her children can have a good education and get to study at the university in order to have a better future than she had and more options in life. For a year she has earned her living selling shoes in the province of Calca and it's going very well. Juana is seeking a loan to buy shoes wholesale so she can continue her shoe business. Juana values and appreciates the loans she has been granted since they allow her to grow and to have a better quality of life, and so she promises to make all of her payments on time.

Translated from Spanish by Jill Heske, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Juana is seeking a loan to buy shoes wholesale so she can keep up her shoe sales business.

loans.name: Anecita

texts.en:
Anecita T. is from the city of Prenza Tangub City. She is 57 years old. Anecita is widowed and has 1 adult child. To make a living, Anecita owns and operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products like soap, shampoo, and milk in the local community. Anecita has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Anecita joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Anecita is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Anecita from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more products to expand the business.

loans.name: Mujeres De Combate (Cuenca) Group

texts.es:
El banco comunal Mujeres de Combate esta formado por un grupo de 10 mujeres quienes se dedican a realizar varias actividades en busca de un mejor futuro para sus familias, son mujeres muy alegres y trabajadoras. Viven en la ciudad de Cuenca, esta ciudad es reconocida por ser la tercera ciudad más importante del Ecuador, fue nombrada el primero de  diciembre de 1999 como Patrimonio Cultural de la Humanidad.

La Señora. Marcia Patricia C.  vive en de la ciudad de Cuenca, tiene 30 años, es casada y tiene 3 hijos, su primer hijo tiene 10 años, sus dos últimos hijos son gemelos de 6 años y  todos  estudian en la escuela, su esposo es chofer y tiene su propio taxi, no tienen casa propia por lo que viven en casa de sus padres pero de una manera independiente.
Nuestra socia es estilista y lleva laborando como profesional hace 14 años, cuenta con su propio gabinete de belleza en el cual labora de lunes a domingo de 8 a.m. a 6 p.m. Es el primer crédito que realiza, fue invitada por una amiga que es socia de la banca comunal, su crédito lo va a invertir en la compra de cosméticos para vender en su local. Su meta es llegar a tener su casa propia.

La Señora. María Adela H. vive por el sector de Huizhil que es perteneciente a la parroquia Baños. Este es su primer crédito y fue invitada por su suegra, nuestra socia se dedica hace un año a la cría de pollos, los que vende pelados o vivos, también se dedica a la venta de productos Yanbal actividad que la realiza hace 7 años. 
La Señora. María Adela tiene 34 años, es casada y tiene una hija de 2 años y 7 meses, su esposo es comerciante de discos compactos, no tienen casa propia por lo que viven en casa de sus suegros pero de manera independiente. Su crédito lo va  a invertir en pollos y también en su alimento. Su sueño es viajar a España.
texts.en:
The Mujeres de Combate (Women of Combat) Community Bank is made up of 10 women who work in a variety of activities to provide a better future for their families. They are very happy and hard-working women. They live in the city of Cuenca, and this city is known as the third most important city in Ecuador. On December 1, 1999, it was recognized as a Cultural Site.

Mrs. Marcia Patricia C. lives in the city of Cuenca, is 30 years old, married, and has 3 children. Her oldest son is 10 years old and the other two are 6 year old twins, and they all are students. Her husband is a taxi driver and has his own taxi. They do not have their own home, but live independently in her parents' home.

This group member has been a professional hair stylist for 14 years. She has her own location where she works from Monday to Sunday from 8:00am until 6:00 pm. This is her first loan, and she was invited to the group by a friend who is a member of the community bank. She will use the loan to buy cosmetics to sell at her business. Her goal is to have her own home.

Mrs. María Adela H. lives in Huizhil in the region of Baños. This is her first loan and she was invited by her mother-in-law. She has worked for a year raising chickens, and she sells them butchered or live. She also has sold Yanbal products for 7 years. She is 34 years old and has a daughter who is 2 years and 7 months old. Her husband sells CDs. They do not have their own home, and live independently in her in-laws' home. She will use the loan to buy chickens and their food. Her dream is to travel to Spain.

Translated from Spanish by Emily Meinecke, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy chickens/food and cosmetics

loans.name: Mary Ann

texts.en:
Mrs. Mary Ann A. is from the P Malig-on, Tinago, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. She is 35 years of age and married to Maurolito A., an overseas seaman who is a Chief cook. She is blessed with 4 children whom are all now school aged. To make a living, she is presently engaged in food business and opened up a new Food Grill near her residence. She also receives support from her husband from his salary. She’s just started this business and earns approximately Php7,000.00 a month from this business activity. 

In the year 2007, Mary Ann joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mary Ann is an active member of PMPC under the Regular Loan Program has successfully repaid a loan of Php30,000.00 She is now requesting a loan amount of Php50,000.00 as her 7th loan to be used for her capital for operating her food grill business. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family, especially in meeting their basic needs, savings for future use, children’s education, loan repayments, insurance, and possible business expansion. 

About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

texts.en:

She’s been engaged in this kind of business for 3 years already and earns approximately Php 6,000 a month from this business activity.

She is now requesting a loan amount of Php 10,000 as her 2nd loan  to be used for her additional capital for her  existing sari-sari store and videogames business. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her general living conditions, especially in meeting her basic needs, savings for future use, loan repayments, insurance and possible business expansion.

As an active member of PMPC under the Regular Loan Program, Marlon has successfully repaid a loan amount of Php 15,000. He is now requesting a loan in the amount of Php 30,000 as his 2nd loan to be used as additional capital for his existing videogames business. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family especially in meeting their basic needs, saving for future use and for the children’s education, loan repayments, insurance and possible business expansion. 

About PMPC:
 Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

She is also receiving support from her husband from his salary as their monthly allotment. She’s been engaged in this kind of business for one year already and earns approximately Php 10,000 a month from this business activity. 

Just this year, Analou joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family, especially in meeting their basic needs, saving for future use and for the children’s education, loan repayments, insurance and possible business expansion.

loans.name: Rehana's Group

texts.en:
Rehana S. lives in a three-room brick house in Lahore which is also known as the heart of Pakistan. She sells clothes part-time to earn an income. She buys clothes from Faisalabad which is famous for its textile industry and sells them in her local market and to her neighborhood clients. She is a  very supportive lady who started this business to help her husband to cover the financial needs of the family. Her husband runs a small cafe in a nearby market where he offers tea and fast food to his customers. 

Although she is a working woman, she never forgets to carry out her responsibilities as a housewife and a mother as well. She is a mother of an only son and has raised him with good manners and discipline. Her son is now a teenager. He performs his duty of  driver for his family: he drives a rickshaw to help his family financially. 

Rehana has applied for a loan for the 3rd time from Asasah for her clothes-selling business. With the loan amount she will buy clothes in bulk and expand her business.  She hopes that she will be able to get positive results from her business after making a greater investment into it.  She also has a plan to build another room on her house so she can marry off her son and take his wife in to a furnished room.

loans.use: Purchase clothes for resale

loans.name: Elvie

texts.en:
Elvie S. is 45 years old, married and has three school-aged children. She is from the village of Barangay Bonfal West in Bayombong municipality, a part of the province of Nueva Vizcaya on the Luzon islands. Elvie owns a general store from which she sells products for daily use such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste to the local community. Elvie has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately 3500 PHP a month.

In 2010, Elvie joined ASKI to gain access to its financial services. She is requesting a new loan, her first from ASKI, of 7000 PHP that will be used to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use all additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family.

About ASKI:

Alalay sa Kaunlaran, Inc., or ASKI, is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishermen and -women, and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Nghiêm

texts.en:
D. Nghiêm Thị (20201020050) is a 26-year-old female living in the town of huyện Yên Phong- tỉnh Bắc Ninh. She is married and has two school-aged children. To making a living, D. owns and operates a business venture in the manufacturing sector. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from manufacturing and selling wood products to local businesses and community members. D. has been engaged in this business for over 6 years and earns approximately 4.200.000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2007 D. joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. D. has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6.048.000 VND from SEDA.  This previous loan was used to purchase raw materials to manufacture additional products. D. is now requesting a new loan of 8.288.000 VND which will be used to purchase raw materials to manufacture additional products. The loan will be the fifth loan taken out by the borrower through SEDA. D. plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About SEDA:

The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide microfinance services to low income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the Northern provinces of Vietnam.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

D. Nghiêm Thị (20201020050) là 26 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố huyện Yên Phong - tỉnh Bắc Ninh.  Cô ấy đã lập gia đình và có 2 trẻ ở độ tuổi đi học.  Để kiếm sống, D. Sở hữu và thực hiện hoạt động kinh doanh.  Công việc kinh doanh hoạt động tại lĩnh vực sản xuất.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh sản xuất.  Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ sản xuất & bán các sản phẩm bằng gỗ cho các doanh nghiệp và người D. trong cộng đồng địa phương.  D. thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 6 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, D. kiếm được khoảng 4.200.000 VND một tháng.

Vào 2007, D. đã tham gia SEDA để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  D. đề nghị khoản vay lần đầu tiên từ SEDA.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua nguyên liệu thô để sản xuất các sản phẩm bổ sung.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 8.288.000 VND.  Khoản vay hiện tại sẽ được sử dụng để mua nguyên liệu thô để sản xuất các sản phẩm bổ sung.  Khoản vay sẽ là 5th khoản vay của người vay từ SEDA.  D. dự định sẽ sử dụng nguồn thu nhập bổ sung từ công việc kinh doanh  cải thiện/ mở rộng công việc kinh doanh của người vay.

Về SEDA:

Nhiệm vụ của SEDA (Trung Tâm hỗ Trợ Phát Triển các Doanh Nghiệp Nhỏ) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính vi mô cho những người có thu nhập thấp và kém may mắn trong các vùng nông thôn tại Hà Nội và các tỉnh phía Bắc Việt Nam

*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.

loans.name: Surraiya Sultana's Group

texts.en:
Surraiya Sultana is a life-long resident of Lahore, the second largest city in Pakistan. She is married to M. Y., a tailor by profession, who operates his tailoring shop in a market nearby. Surraiya is the mother of two sons, both of whom do embroidery work. They were unable to complete their education due to poor financial conditions, so their father sent them to an embroidery shop to learn the art of embroidery. They trained for three years and now are able to do quality work themselves.

For the past eighteen years Surraiya has been selling ready-made clothes to neighborhood clients which she purchases from Anaarkali, a famous cloth market in Lahore. Each member of her family is employed and together they manage the family’s expenses. But as inflation increases, to survive in a big city like Lahore where the cost of living is so high one must work ever harder to save money for rainy days.

Therefore, Surraiya has applied for a loan for the second time from Asasah for the expansion of her ready-made garments business. With the loan amount she will purchase garments in bulk and so hopes to increase her earnings.

loans.use: To purchase ready-made garments for selling

loans.name: Vira

texts.en:
Mr. Vira U. (because he was not available for the photo, his wife stood in for him ) and his wife, Mrs. Sa-um, live on an island in the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. They have been married since 1975 and have seven children: four sons and three daughters. Three of them are married and live outside the family home; two are garment factory workers; one assists his parents in the farming business, while another attends school.

Vira grows taro and papaya on his farmland in the village, assisted by his wife, a scarf weaver. Vira has received several loans already, and he now is requesting another loan in the amount of $300 to build a restroom for his family’s use.

loans.use: To build a restroom for his family’s use.

loans.name: Chanthorn

texts.en:
Mrs. Chanthorn T. (in the photo), and her husband, Mr. Chantha Thorn, have been married since 2007 and have one young daughter. They live with her mother and brother on an island on the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Chanthorn has been a silk weaver since she was seventeen yeas old. She sells her finished products to the village middleman, who then takes them to Phnom Penh market or other places. She asked for a Kiva loan one time already. She is now applying for another loan in the amount of US$ 700 to purchase silk material to continue her weaving business and repair the house where she lives.

loans.use: To buy weaving materials and repair the house where she lives

loans.name: Sokleang

texts.en:
Mr. Sokleang K. (pictured with his wife), is 40 years old, and his wife, Mrs. Ros Chea, is 40 years old. They have been married since 1994 and have four sons. All of them are in school.  The family lives in a village along National Road Number One about seventeen kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Sokleang and his wife are farmers. They grow vegetables on their farmland in the village. Sokleang is applying for a loan in the amount of US$ 500 to buy bamboo nets to build a shelter to shield his vegetables from the sun.

loans.use: To buy bamboo and nets to build a shelter for his vegetables

This will be Myrna's third loan from ASKI, and she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her enterprise.

loans.name: 05.05.03 Dinh Long - Hoang Phong - Hoang Hoa Group

texts.en:
Lý H. Thị (50503006) is a 24-year-old female living in the town of Hoằng Hóa, Thanh Hóa. Lý is the leader of a six-member group loan offered by Kiva partner, Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 050503-Đình Long-Hoằng Phong (050503-Đình Long-Hoằng Phong).
Lý is married and has one infant-aged child. To make a living, Lý operates a family member's business venture in the agriculture sector raising chickens for sale. She has been engaged in this business for over four years and earns approximately 1,000,000 VND a month from these activities.
In 2010, Lý joined Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting her first loan from Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women for 4,248,000 VND, which will be used to purchase breeding livestock. Lý plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.

About the other borrowers in the group
1. Lê Thị Hiền (50503007) is a 37-year-old female who is requesting a 2,442,600 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock. 2. C. Thị Bính (50503008) is a 35-year-old female who is requesting a 3,079,800 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock. 3. N. About Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women
The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainable financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Lý H. Thị (50503006) là 24 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Hoằng Hóa - Thanh Hóa. Lý là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 6 các thành viên. Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ.. Từ các hoạt động này, Lý kiếm được khoảng 1,000,000 VND. Vào 2010, Lý đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy. Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva. ."

loans.use: To purchase breeding livestock

loans.name: Samina's Group

texts.en:
Samina is a working woman who has a business selling clothes. She lives with her family in the historic city of Lahore in Pakistan. Samina is a widow who lost her husband a few years ago as a result of sudden death. Samina has worked very hard with her children. She not only works but gives full-time attention to her children as they grow up. She has two sons: the elder sells newspapers and the younger sells clothes with his mother.
Samina has applied for a loan for the third time from Kiva partner, Asasah, for her clothes-selling business. With her loan, she will buy a range of different clothes in bulk. She has been engaged in this business for over 15 years and hopes that she will be able to make a good profit and improve her family's standard of living.
Samina is a regular borrower from Asasah. In the past two years, she has maintained good credit behavior and never missed a single meeting.

loans.use: To purchase clothes for resale

loans.name: Norma

texts.en:
Norma P. is from the village of Cabisera 5. She is 55 years old, married, and has three adult-aged children. To make a living, Norma owns and operates a specialized retail store selling fruits and vegetables in the local community. Norma has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 4,500 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2010, Norma joined Kiva partner, ASKI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. This loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Norma is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will also be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her second from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About ASKI
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Jessica

texts.en: This is 21-year-old Jessica L.. She is married and has no children. In 2010, she established her tailoring business. Working 7 days a week and 5 hours a day, she supports her family. In the future, Jessica plans to earn more in tailoring. She thanks you for your support. In the Kathmandu Valley, clothing is made to order. Tailor stalls line the streets where store owners sell material and work their sewing machines. These skilled tailors make school uniforms for children as well as the the traditional women's kurta surwal and men's daura surwal. With a Kiva loan, BPW borrowers are able to purchase additional cloth material or sewing machines that will increase production and profitability. This loan was administered by Kiva's local partner MFI, Patan Business and Professional Women. Patan BPW became Kiva's first field partner in Nepal in 2007. Patan BPW operates throughout the Kathmandu Valley, offering microcredit and business training programs to low-income women. In addition to providing economic opportunity to their clients, Patan BPW seeks to empower Nepali women within the home and community. For more information about Patan BPW, visit our partner page and keep an eye out for new loans and borrower updates: BPW Partner Page Join our lending team: BPW Lending Team

loans.use: starting a tailoring business

loans.name: Seti Maya

texts.en: This is 45-year-old Seti Maya B.. She is married and has 3 children aged 20, 14 and 10. In 2000, she established her agriculture business. Working 7 days a week and 10 hours a day, she supports her family. In the future, Seti Maya plans to earn more in farming. She thanks you for your support. Over 70% of Nepal's economy is agricultural. Typically, Nepali households grow crops on small plots of terraced land. Rice (bhat), lentils (daal), and vegetables (thakari) are the staples of the Nepali diet. With a Kiva loan, BPW's borrowers are able to purchase greater amounts of seed and fertilizer. With more seeds and fertilizer, a borrower is able to grow cash crops to be sold in the local market. Such crops allow households to move beyond subsistence and provide much-needed cash income throughout the year. This loan was administered by Kiva's local partner MFI, Patan Business and Professional Women. Patan BPW became Kiva's first field partner in Nepal in 2007. Patan BPW operates throughout the Kathmandu Valley, offering microcredit and business training programs to low-income women. In addition to providing economic opportunity to their clients, Patan BPW seeks to empower Nepali women within the home and community. For more information about Patan BPW, visit our partner page and keep an eye out for new loans and borrower updates: BPW Partner Page Join our lending team: BPW Lending Team

loans.use: purchase seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Nghiêm

texts.en: H. Nghiêm Thị (20201020051) is a 31 year old female living in the town of Huyện Yên Phong - Tỉnh Bắc Ninh. She is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, H. owns and operates a business raising ducks for sale. H. has been engaged in this business for over 3 years and earns approximately 3,600,000 VND a month from these activities. In 2009, H. joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. H. has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,152,000 VND from SEDA. This previous loan was used to purchase feed and other supplies. H. is now requesting a new loan of 8,288,000 VND which will be used to purchase feed and other supplies. The loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by H. from SEDA. H. plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About SEDA: The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide microfinance services to the low-income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the Northern provinces of Vietnam. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders. H. Nghiêm Thị (20201020051) là 31 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy sống ở thành phố huyện Yên Phong - tỉnh Bắc Ninh. Cô ấy đã lập gia đình và có 2 trẻ ở độ tuổi đi học. Để kiếm sống, H. Sở hữu và thực hiện hoạt động kinh doanh. Công việc kinh doanh hoạt động tại lĩnh vực nông nghiệp. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc. Trong khi không phải chỉ có các pH. thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ chăn nuôi vịt để bán. H. thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 3 năm. Từ các hoạt động này, H. kiếm được khoảng 3.600.000 VND một tháng. Vào 2009, H. đã tham gia SEDA để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy. H. đề nghị khoản vay lần đầu tiên từ SEDA. Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua thức ăn gia súc & các loại cung cấp khác. Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 8.288.000 VND. Khoản vay hiện tại sẽ được sử dụng để mua thức ăn gia súc & các loại cung cấp khác. Khoản vay sẽ là 2nd khoản vay của người vay từ SEDA. H. dự định sẽ sử dụng nguồn thu nhập bổ sung từ công việc kinh doanh cải thiện/ mở rộng công việc kinh doanh của người vay. Về SEDA: Nhiệm vụ của SEDA (Trung Tâm hỗ Trợ Phát Triển các Doanh Nghiệp Nhỏ) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính vi mô cho những người có thu nhập thấp và kém may mắn trong các vùng nông thôn tại Hà Nội và các tỉnh phía Bắc Việt Nam *Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. . Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.

loans.use: to purchase feed and other supplies

loans.name: Bishnu

texts.en: This is 36-year-old Bishnu L.. She is married and has 3 children aged 14, 10 and 8. In 2001, she established her service business. Working 7 days a week and 8 hours a day, she supports her family. She has already received and successfully repaid 1 loan from Patan BPW and used her most recent to purchase vegetables from others to sell. In the future, Bishnu plans to earn more in vegetable business. She thanks you for your support. In the Kathmandu Valley, the small grocery store, called a pasal, is an important part of the local economy. Fresh produce, milk, and staples such as rice, lentils, and flour are purchased daily for cooking in the home. Owners of small grocery stores use Kiva loans to increase their purchasing power and profit margains. By keeping inventory strong and purchasing in larger amounts, owners of these small stores are able to increase profitability. While a typical pasal might be no more than 100 sq. feet, they are always full of bargaining customers, incoming produce, and shrewd businesswomen. This loan was administered by Kiva's local partner MFI, Patan Business and Professional Women. Patan BPW became Kiva's first field partner in Nepal in 2007. Patan BPW operates throughout the Kathmandu Valley, offering microcredit and business training programs to low-income women. In addition to providing economic opportunity to their clients, Patan BPW seeks to empower Nepali women within the home and community. For more information about Patan BPW, visit our partner page and keep an eye out for new loans and borrower updates: BPW Partner Page Join our lending team: BPW Lending Team

loans.name: Nguyễn's Group

texts.en: Hà Nguyễn Thị (20201020048) is a 28 year-old female living in the town of Huyện Yên Phong - Tỉnh Bắc Ninh. Hà is the group leader of a 2-member group loan offered by SEDA. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Nghiêm Xá Nhóm 14 (Nhóm 14). Hà is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Hà owns and operates a business raising pigs for sale. Hà has been engaged in this business for over 5 years and earns approximately 3,800,000 VND a month from these activities. In 2007, Hà joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Hà has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,048,000 VND from SEDA. This previous loan was used to purchase baby pigs to raise and sell in the future. She is now requesting a new loan of 8,288,000 VND which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. The loan will be the 5th loan taken out by her from SEDA. loans.use: to purchase baby pigs to raise and sell in future

loans.name: Narangerel

texts.en:
Narangerel is 33 years old, married, and has a 12-year-old son and a 6-year-old daughter. Currently they live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. 

During this summer she and her husband built a 48 square meter wooden house on their piece of land. The reason she is asking for this loan is they plan to finish the internal decorations and to move in to their newly built house before winter comes. 

Narangerel used to work in a clothing factory and was left jobless because the factory closed down. Then she started her own tailoring business and employs two tailors, paying them 150,000 Mongolian tugrug (MNT) a month each. She makes protective clothing such as gloves and overalls and sells them in the market. She rents two stalls in "Harhorin" the second largest market in Ulaanbaatar city and sells garments as well. She is very hard-working, enthusiastic person. Her future plan is to expand her business and to give a good education to her kids.

loans.use: Finishing internal decorations for newly built house

loans.name: Lucia Elizabeth

texts.es: Lucia Elizabeth D. D. M. D. 40 años D. edad, resiD. en Santiago Nonualco, ubicado en el departamento D. Usulután. En este lugar vive junto a su familia la cual esta conformada por su esposo y sus tres hijos D. 8, 3 y 1 año D. edad. Lucia trabaja vendiendo ropa para mujeres y niños, así mismo comercializa joyería como: cadenas, aritos, pulseras y anillos entre otros más, los cuales son D. enchape D. oro, los precios que ella ofrece son muy buenos, y así mismo la calidad del producto que ofrece es excelente, por lo que cuenta con varios clientes, los cuales realizan compras frecuentes. Lucia comercializa la mayoría D. la ropa y joyería a crédito, y es una mínima cantidad la que ofrece a contado, debido a las facilidades D. pago que ella ofrece, es que pueD. contar con varios clientes. Lucia solicita un préstamo con el deseo D. poder contar con el dinero necesario para comprar mayor cantidad D. ropa y joyería, y así mismo comprar mayor variedad, D. forma que sus clientes se sientan satisfechos, esto lo hace con el enorme deseo D. poder obtener más ganancias y D. esta forma mejorar la estabilidad económica D. su familia.
texts.en:
Lucia Elizabeth D. D. M. is 40 years old and lives in Santiago Nonualco, located in the Usulután department. She lives with her family which includes her husband and three children, ages 8, 3, and 1. Lucia sells women’s and children’s clothing. She also sells jewelry, such as chains, earrings, bracelets, and rings, among other gold plated things. Her prices are very good and the quality of her merchandise is excellent. She has steady customers who buy from her frequently. Lucia sells most of her clothing and jewelry on credit and sells very little for cash. Because of her simple payment terms, she is able to count on many customers. [She] is asking for this loan so that she can buy bulk quantities of clothing and jewelry in greater varieties. This will better satisfy her customers. She has a great desire to increase her income and bring greater financial stability to her family.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Inventory

location.town: Santiago Nonualco, departamento de La Paz

loans.name: Manuel De Jesús

texts.es: Manuel de Jesús P. de 34 años de edad, reside en San Martín, departamento de San Salvador en donde vive junto a su esposa, la cual trabaja como comerciante de productos varios. Manuel se dedica a la venta de ropa para hombres mujeres y niños, así mismo comercializa cortinas, manteles, ropa de cama y otra variedad más, él es un hombre con una amplia experiencia en el trabajo que realiza ya que cuenta con 18 años de dedicarse a la venta de ropa. Manuel distribuye su producto en el mercado de San Martín, en donde cuenta con una ruta determinada de clientes, así mismo comercializa en el pueblo de Cojutepeque y en el centro de San Salvador, en donde vende de forma ambulante, lo cual le permite percibir mayores ganancias. Él es una persona muy trabajadora y dedicada al bienestar de su hogar, por lo que se esfuerza días tras días por dar lo mejor. Manuel solicita un préstamo con el deseo de poder comprar mayor cantidad de ropa y de esta forma surtir el negocio con más variedad y diferentes estilos, lo que le permitirá abrirse nuevos campos con diferentes clientes.
texts.en:
Manuel de Jesús P. is 34 years old and lives with his wife in San Martín, within the San Salvador department. His wife sells various products. Manuel sells men's, women's and children's clothing, as well as drapes, table cloths, pajamas, and other items. He is very experienced in his work because he has been selling clothing for 18 years. Manuel sells his products in the San Martín market, where he has a steady stream of customers. He also sells in the town of Cojutepeque in the center of San Salvador, where he sells on foot. This allows him to maximize his income. He is a hard worker who is dedicated to his household and works daily to provide the best for it. Manuel is asking for this loan in order to buy clothing in bulk to be able to supply his business with a greater quantity and variety of styles. This will allow him to open new doors with different customers.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Inventory

loans.name: Ana María

texts.es: Ana María H. D. L. D. 34 años D. edad, es una señora muy trabajadora y responsable con su hogar, ya que a diario sabe dedicarse D. lleno a su trabajo y a su familia y el bienestar D. su casa. Ella vive junto a su esposo el cual trabaja como profesor, y así mismo vive junto a dos t hijos D. 18 y 10 años D. edad, los cuales se dedican a estudiar y junto a quienes resiD. en el departamento D. Ahuachapán. Ana trabaja comercializando productos D. belleza como maquillaje, perfumes, joyería, productos para el hogar, carteras y muchos otros artículos más, los cuales son pedidos por catalogo, el cual se dedica a mostrar haciendo visitas D. casa en casa con sus vecinos, familiares y amigos, este tipo D. revista ha venido a ser muy popular entre las personas ya que las vendedoras D. este productos brindan la facilidad D. pagar a crédito a al contado. Es por esta razón que ella solicita un préstamo a Integral para que D. esta forma ella cuente con el dinero necesario para hacer los pedidos hechos por sus clientes y D. esta forma invertir en el negocio, lo cual se le hace bastante difícil debido a que la mayoría D. sus ventas son a crédito, lo que le dificulta comprar más productos o hacer más pedido. Ana cuenta con mucho optimismo ya que espera realizar todo lo anterior y mejorar su negocio, gracias al préstamo solicitado.
texts.en:
Ana María H. D. L. is 34 years old and is a very hard working, woman responsible for her home. She is dedicated to her work and to her family’s well being every day. She lives with her husband, who works as a teacher, and with her two children, ages 18 and 10, who attend school. They all live together in the Ahuachapán department. Ana sells beauty products, such as makeup, perfumes, jewelry, household items, wallets, and many other items through catalogs. She goes door to door to her neighbors, family, and friends to show her products. These types of sales have become very popular because the salespeople make it easy for customers to buy either on credit or in cash. It is for this reason that she is requesting this loan through Integral. She wants to be able to have the money that she needs to process the orders that her customers have placed. She also wants to be able to invest in her business because she finds it difficult to do at this time, since most of her sales are by credit, which itself makes it difficult for her to buy more merchandise or process additional orders. Ana is very optimistic and expects to achieve all of these things and also improve her business, thanks to this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Inventory

loans.name: Pablo Heriberto

texts.es: Pablo Heriberto R. de 39 años de edad,  reside en el hermoso pueblo de Alegría, ubicado en el departamento de Usulután, en donde vive junto a su compañera de vida, la cual le ayuda a Pablo con el negocio. Él posee una venta de comida típica como: pupusas, empanadas, pastelitos, yuca frita y muchos más, los cuales son elaborados por su esposa, estos alimentos son comercializados en su casa de habitación en donde cada tarde colocan una mesa con todo los antojitos y de esta forma los venden con personas que viven alrededor o que transitan por el lugar. Pablo se encarga de vender y cobrar los productos, y de esta forma ambos trabajan en conjunto para poder sacarle el mayor provecho a su negocio, el cual desde hace 2 años les permite contar con todo lo necesario y esencial para vivir. Pablo solicita un préstamo con el enorme deseo de poder comprar mayor cantidad de materia prima para la elaboración de dichos alimentos, productos como: maíz, verduras, frijoles, arroz, vinagre y otros más, los cuales le permitirán tanto a Pablo como a su esposo poder elaborar mayor cantidad de platillos y de esta forma aumentar sus ventas.
texts.en:
Pablo Heriberto R. is 39 years old. He resides in the beautiful village of Alegría, in the department of Usulután, with his life partner, who helps Pablo with the business. He has a sales stand where he sells traditional foods such as pupusas [filled tortillas], empanadas, pastelitos [stuffed pastries], fried yuca, and much more. The food is prepared by his wife and sold from their house. Each evening, they set out a table with all of the snacks, so that people living nearby or passing through can buy the food. Pablo is in charge of selling the products and handling the money, and in this way they work together to get the most out of their business. For the past 2 years, this work has allowed them to support themselves with all that is necessary and essential in their daily lives. Pablo is requesting a loan with the strong desire to purchase a larger quantity of ingredients and supplies (such as corn, vegetables, beans, rice, vinegar, among others) in order to prepare a greater amount of food and thus increase his sales.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying ingredients and supplies to prepare food

loans.name: Niymat

texts.en:
Niymat R. was born and lived in the Republic of Tadjikistan. He grew up in a large family with 12 children. From early childhood he had to help his parents in the field where his family cultivated potatoes and cotton. After serving in the army, Niymat returned home and began to work as a builder.  He was 27 years old when he married and soon became the father of twins – a boy and a girl.  

Niymat didn’t want to stay to his native village because of civil war in Tadjikistan. He took his family and in 1999 moved to the central part of Kyrgyzstan, Ivanovka village. Using the money he had earned, Niymat bought a house and one bull-calf for fattening.  Also, he planted vegetables--cucumbers, tomatoes, eggplants, and potatoes on the plot of land.  

Niymat didn’t have any experience in cattle breeding, however within 10 years he multiplied the number of cattle. Today, he has one cow, two calves and one bull-calf. Being very purposeful and positive person, Niymat works hard to support his family.

Niymat plans to use this loan of 30,000 Kyrgyz Soms to increase the number of cattle. In the future, Niymat is planning to give higher education to his children and build a house for his son. He also plans to marry his daughter off and wants to see his grandchildren. 

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population.

Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Felicitas

texts.en: Felicitas M. is from the village of Allinguigan 3rd. She is 51 years old. Felicitas is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Felicitas makes and sells food. The main source of income for the business comes from preparing and selling cooked food for daily meals. Felicitas has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 4,500 Philippines pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2009, Felicitas joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Felicitas has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to prepare food for sale. Felicitas is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP, which will also be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Felicitas from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Firuza

texts.en: Firuza A. is 44 years old. She is married with two adult children. For almost for 16 years, Firuza has been in the bridal salon business. Every day, she provides services to many brides. In general, she offers bridal dresses and decorations for wedding cars. Her salon is always full of clients, because she does her job professionally. Firuza wants to take a loan to extend her business. She wants to buy additional wedding dresses and decorations. Firuza likes her job very much because she likes to see the smiles of happy brides every day. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes being a key post along the Silk Road, and for the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing goods for bridal shop

She was introduced to KADET by her friend. This will be her first loan. She plans to use the cash to buy more goats, which she will rear and sell later at a profit.

Jackline also hopes to start selling paraffin as a secondary business. Paraffin is in high demand in Naivasha town, and she believes it will be profitable. She hopes to grow her business and improve the family's standard of living.

loans.name: Olivia

texts.en:
N. Olivia is 19 years old and lives in the town of Mukono in the Mukono region of Uganda.  She is single and has no children.  Olivia has a boutique, which she has had for one year.         

To help expand her business, Olivia has requested a loan of 150,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more clothes.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Olivia hopes to generate greater profits and to take care of herself by buying food and clothes for herself. In the future, Olivia hopes to own a house. 

Note to lenders: BRAC Uganda has recently begun posting a new loan product to Kiva which funds young entrepreneurs in BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program.  This Kiva borrower is receiving a new ELA loan. The ELA program first provides disadvantaged adolescents, usually girls who are out of school, with livelihood training and financial literacy skills.  Afterward, ELA participants can receive microfinance loans to expand their small businesses.  These loans offer adolescents a unique chance to access finance at a young age and improve their prospects for the future, and target a segment of the population not typically served by traditional microfinance.  Kiva is privileged to partner with BRAC Uganda in posting these new loans, and give Kiva lenders the opportunity to fund deserving young entrepreneurs and support a promising new sector in microfinance.

loans.name: Margret

texts.en:
N. Margret is 19 years old and lives in the town of Mukono in the Mukono region of Uganda.  She is single and has no children Margret has had a business selling food like matooke and sweet potatoes for two years.  

To help expand her business, Margret has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more food.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Margret hopes to generate greater profits, sometimes to buy food and to take care of herself.  In the future, Margret hopes to own a house.    

Note to lenders: BRAC Uganda has recently begun posting a new loan product to Kiva, which funds young entrepreneurs in BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program.  This Kiva borrower is receiving a new ELA loan. The ELA program first provides disadvantaged adolescents, usually girls who are out of school, with livelihood training and financial literacy skills.  Afterward, ELA participants can receive microfinance loans to expand their small businesses.  These loans offer adolescents a unique chance to access finance at a young age and improve their prospects for the future, and target a segment of the population not typically served by traditional microfinance.  Kiva is privileged to partner with BRAC Uganda in posting these new loans, and give Kiva lenders the opportunity to fund deserving young entrepreneurs and support a promising new sector in microfinance.

loans.use: To buy more food like matooke

loans.name: Betheljane

texts.en:
Betheljane O. is from the village of Tambo, Macasandig, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 19 years old. Betheljane is married and has two infant children. To make a living, Betheljane owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Betheljane has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Betheljane joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Betheljane is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Betheljane from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Malakhat

texts.en:
Malakhat M. is a 57-year-old woman who has been engaged in poultry and cattle breeding for the last two years. She is a very successful entrepreneur who sells chicken, which brings her a stable income. 

Malakhat  is married and has three children. She is also working as a teacher in a local school but her salary is about $100, which is very low. Poultry breeding is the main source of income in her family. 

She also keeps a cow for milk and milk products for her family. Now she is ready to purchase one more cow to start selling milk. For this purpose, Malakhat applied for a 900 Azerbaijan New Manat (AZN) loan to purchase one dairy cow and some chickens. Milk and milk products are very profitable as they in very high demand in Azerbaijan.

loans.use: Purchase one dairy cow and 6 chickens

loans.name: Azizah

texts.en:

To help expand her business, Azizah has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more oil for hair and braids in her salon. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Azizah hopes to generate greater profits and to buy food and clothing for herself.  In the future, Azizah hopes to own a house.        


Note to lenders: BRAC Uganda has recently begun posting a new loan product to Kiva which funds young entrepreneurs in BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. This Kiva borrower is receiving a new ELA loan. The ELA program first provides disadvantaged adolescents, usually girls who are out of school, with livelihood training and financial literacy skills. Afterward, ELA participants can receive microfinance loans to expand their small businesses. These loans offer adolescents a unique chance to access finance at a young age and to improve their prospects for the future, and targets a segment of the population not typically served by traditional microfinance. loans.name: Kilengo Ole

texts.en:
Kilengo has been rearing cattle to sell in Naivasha town for the last three years. He is 24 years old, is married to Matayian Ene Kipino, and they have three children.

Kilengo was introduced to KADET by his friend and has no history with any other microfinance institute, this being his first loan. He plans to use the money to buy more cattle which he will add to his herd and later sell to his customers.

Naivasha is a place well known for its nyama choma zone. Nyama choma is a Kiswahili phrase that actually means open barbecue (meat roasting), and many people go to this place during the holiday seasons to roast beef and goat. So this business of buying and selling of animals is very common in this region.

Kilengo hopes to have a big ranch where he will raise his animals and sell them to his customers.

loans.use: To buy more cattle to raise and sell

loans.name: Chuluunbat

texts.en:
Chuluunbat is 42 years old and lives with his wife and their 2 children and 3 grandchildren in his own ger, a  traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. He has three other children who are grown up and live separately. Before 2005 he used to rent a stall in a local market to sell garments.

In 2005 he improved his business, bought a minivan, obtained a license for carrying people and started a transportation business. During this time he has been four times nominated as the "Best worker of the year" by his employers. 

His route is 50 km's long and he runs this route  5 to 6  a day, carrying passengers all year around.  Chuluunbat has taken the loan from our organisation 4 times and each time he has repaid in full and on time. He has become one of our reliable customers. He used these loans to build a house for his son, who was just married. 

Chuluunbat is very responsible, hardworking person. He is asking for this loan, because winter time is coming and he wants to buy spare parts and make proper repairs and maintenance on his minivan and also to build a warm garage to his car.

loans.use: to repair his minivan and build a garage to prepare for winter's cold

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
K. Betty is 21years old and lives in the town of Kyengera in the Kampala west region of Uganda.  She is married and has 1 child who is  currently in school.  Betty has a business of selling snacks, which she has had for 6 years.         

To help expand her business, Betty has requested a loan of 100,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase and buy more oil, flour and charcoal.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Betty hopes to generate greater profits and to buy food for her family.  In the future, Betty hopes to own a house

Note to lenders: BRAC Uganda has recently begun posting a new loan product to Kiva which funds young entrepreneurs in BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program.  This Kiva borrower is receiving a new ELA loan. The ELA program first provides disadvantaged adolescents, usually girls who are out of school, with livelihood training and financial literacy skills.  Afterward, ELA participants can receive microfinance loans to expand their small businesses.  These loans offer adolescents a unique chance to access finance at a young age and improve their prospects for the future, and target a segment of the population not typically served by traditional microfinance.  Kiva is privileged to partner with BRAC Uganda in posting these new loans, and give Kiva lenders the opportunity to fund deserving young entrepreneurs and support a promising new sector in microfinance.

loans.name: Khursheed Begum's Group

texts.en:
Khursheed begum has six children - three sons and three daughters - and lives Multan, a historic city in Pakistan. She makes a living embroidering clothing for people living in her neighborhood.  
None of her three sons were able to complete their education, as they had to start working to help their family. They all do different kinds of jobs to earn income: the eldest son has a brick-selling business; the middle one does embroidery; and the youngest one has a job in the private sector. Khursheed’s husband works for a Municipal Corporation; however, his income is not sufficient for supporting the family. Therefore, Khursheed, with the help of a loan from Asasah, started the embroidery business to share the financial burden with her husband. Over the past few years, Khurseed has borrowed from Asasah three times and has maintained a good credit record every year.
Now, Khurseed has applied for a new loan from Asasah, which will be her fourth one, and which she will use to expand her embroidery business by buying additional embroidery materials, such as beads, cloth, colored thread, and sketches. She hopes that the expansion will help her increase the business profits and, in turn, allow her to provide sufficient dowry for her elder daughter, who is nearing marriage age.

loans.use: Purchase of embroidery material in bulk to expand embroidery business

texts.en:
N. Hellen is 17 years old and lives in the town of Kyengera, in the Kampala West region of Uganda. She is single and has no children. For over a year now, Hellen has been running her own poultry-rearing business to make a living.          

To help expand her business, Hellen is now requesting a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more chicken for rearing, and Hellen hopes that the expansion will increase her business profits and allow her to afford to buy sufficient food and, in the future, pay for her university studies.

Afterward, ELA participants can receive microfinance loans to expand their small businesses. Kiva is privileged to partner with BRAC Uganda in posting these new loans, and give Kiva lenders the opportunity to fund deserving young entrepreneurs and support a promising new sector in microfinance.

loans.name: 080805-Hoang Thinh Group

texts.en:
Vinh Lê Thị, 44, lives in the town of Hoằng Hóa - Thanh Hóa.  Vinh is the leader of a 5-member group - officially called 080805-Hoang thinh - that is requesting a loan from the Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. While each group member receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. 

Vinh is married and has 3 school-aged children.  To making a living, she operates a family business in the agriculture sector, raising livestock, particularly chickens, for sale. Vinh has been engaged in this business for over 15 years and earns approximately 600,000 VND a month.

In 2004, Vinh joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Vinh has successfully repaid a previous loan of 2,124,000 VND from the Fund, which she used to purchase livestock for breeding.  Now, she is requesting a new loan of 1,062,000 VND, which will be used for the same purpose, and which will be her 9th loan from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Vinh plans to use the additional revenue to further improve and expand her business.

About the group's other borrowers:

1.  Lê Thị Yến, 38, is requesting a loan of 3,079,800 VND to support her livestock-breeding business.

2.  N. Thị Lý, 29, is requesting a loan of 2,442,600 VND for her livestock-breeding business.

3.  H. Thị Hải, 55, is requesting a loan of 2,124,000 VND to support her livestock business.

4.  Lê D. Niên, 29, is requesting a loan of 2,124,000 VND for her livestock business.

About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainable financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.
