loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
The Kiva borrower is a 30-year old married man with two young children, who are attending school. He is the main income provider for his family. He has 19 years of experience working as a carpenter. He has been running his own carpentry business since 2006. His job consists of buying woods and cutting it in different designs.  He distributes his products to different galleries and he also works on request of the clients. He has multiple catalogs to allow his customers to choose from various designs. He works independently in his business. 

Today, he is requesting a loan of $1000 to purchase additional wood for his work. With the additional wood, he will be able to increase his production and so his income. He estimates that the loan will help him increase his profits in the coming months.

Note: Based on the political and social challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e., blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, not indicating his/her name and location, etc.) Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Lebanon's borrowers.

About Ameen:
Ameen s.a.l. has been a major player in the Lebanese Microfinance sector since 1999. Originally, a micro-credit program created by CHF International, Ameen evolved to become Ameen s.a.l. in 2003, a Lebanese services company. In 2007, Ameen s.a.l. registered with the Central Bank of Lebanon to become the first Lebanese financial institution specialized in Microfinance.

At Ameen s.a.l. we pledge to provide financial services to the largest number of micro and small entrepreneurs and to the working poor, to help them develop their businesses and improve their incomes.

Ameen has been able to use its interest-free loans Kiva to offer lower-interest loans with faster disbursement for their micro-loan borrowers. Since its inception, Ameen has provided high-quality financial services to over 41,000 borrowers and disbursed over 81,000 loans totaling $115 million. To learn more about Ameen, please visit http://partners.kiva.org/partners/115

loans.use: To purchase additional wood supply.

loans.name: Allah Ditti's Group

texts.en:
Allah Ditti lives in the historic city of Pakistan called Multan. She is the mother of five daughters and two sons. All of the children are getting their education except the youngest one, at just 3 years of age. 

It is quite difficult for Allah Ditti and her husband to provide the basic necessities of life for their seven children. That’s why Allaha Ditti started the business of making shawls. She is used to collecting orders from her near-by areas and provide the shawls on order. 

Her husband has a bicycle repairing and welding shop. His business is doing well, but not enough to cover their expenses. Allah Ditti has applied for a loan for the fourth time from Asasah. This time she will invest the loan amount in her husband’s business. He wants to start a rent-a-bike business. With the help of a loan, he will buy a second-hand motorbike which will help him start this rent-a-bike business.

Allah Ditti hopes that the new business will help her husband improve his family's life. He will be able to provide better education facilities to his children. 
She is a regular loan user of Asasah and has maintained a good credit record every year.

loans.use: To purchase a second hand motor-bike for starting a rent a bike business.

loans.name: Frederick

texts.en:
Frederick V. is from Barangay Salamague, Lamut, Ifugao. He is 33 years old. Frederick is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Frederick raises livestock, primarily pigs, for breeding. Frederick has been engaged in his business for over 4 years and earns approximately 7,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Frederick joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. Frederick is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This will be the first loan taken out by Frederick from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed & other supplies.

loans.name: Millicent

texts.en: Millicent is a 40 year old married lady.  For ten years, she has been operating a salon. Since she joined Lifestyle group in Faulu Kenya, her business has really improved. This is because she previously serviced three loans from Faulu Kenya. She has been successful in repaying her loans, hence she has been guaranteed another loan of 50,000 KES. She will use the money to add inventory of make-up and cosmetics. She hopes to expand her business for better income so as to invest in building her own home in the future. She dreams of opening many outlets in ten years.

loans.use: To add inventory of make-up and cosmetics.

loans.name: Bridget

texts.en: Bridget is a 27-year-old single lady. She has a one-year-old son. She has been selling secondhand clothes and shoes for seven months. She was previously selling water to earn a living. Since she joined Faulu Kenya, she has become self-reliant because her business has grown. She is requesting 20,000 KES from Faulu Kenya. This will be her first loan, and she will use it as capital to start a business selling cosmetics. She hopes to expand her business so as to employ people.

loans.use: To start selling cosmetics

loans.name: Felicitas

texts.en: Felicitas A. is from the village of Manano, Mallig. She is 58 years old. Felicitas is married. To make a living, Felicitas runs a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products, such as candy and cold drinks, to the local community. Felicitas has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 4,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2006, Felicitas joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Felicitas has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Felicitas is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This will be the second loan taken out by Felicitas from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand her product offering

loans.name: Makindye Development Group-Kampala

texts.en:
Any upstart in business knows that seeking knowledge from somebody who is a past master at running a successful business will always be a worthwhile experience. In 35-year-old Margeret N.’s case, her brother gave her the pep talk to begin her cosmetics sales business six years ago in Nabiseelu-Kampala. 

This being her first business, she gave it her best shot. She rose to the occasion and with determination in tow, she got into her progressive stride early enough. Her unwavering sense of enterprise has enabled her come up with new ideas every time, aimed at consolidating the gains she has made over the course of these last years.  

The satisfactory rate of progress she has achieved sees her weekly balance-sheet profits totaling to 150,000 shillings. This married mother of three also operates a soft-drinks selling business. With this loan, she wants to buy more cosmetics in bulk for resale.

loans.use: The purchase of more cosmetics in bulk for resale

loans.name: Mussarat's Group

texts.en:
Mussarat lives in a historic city of Pakistan called Multan. She is the mother of three daughters and a son. All of them are very young and attending school. Her husband is a salesman. He sells different kind of products in different areas and markets. 

She helps her husband financially by doing embroidery works. She has hired a worker who collects orders for her and she completes orders on time to earn a profit. She has been doing this work for over 18 years and has much experience in this field. She has also started selling bangles recently, which has started making her good profits also. 

She lives with her family in a small house of two rooms. She has minimized her expenses to survive financially but she wants her family to have a better standard of living. 

She has applied for a loan from Asasah for her embroidery business. With the loan amount, she will buy embroidery material in bulk that will help her to improve her business condition. She is a new loan user of Asasah and she hopes that this step will prove successful for her business. 

Note: In this photo, Mussarat is wearing the bangles in her group member Samina's hand.

loans.use: Purchase embroidery material for improving her embroidery business

loans.name: Frorence

texts.en: Frorence is married with four children who are in school.  She owns and operates a retail shop.  She has been in the business for five years.  She also sells clothes to supplement her family’s income.  She has requested a loan of 30,000 KES to add to the stock of clothing in her boutique.  She also wants to buy sugar, cooking fat, and maize flour in order to expand what her shop offers.

loans.use: To purchase clothing for her shop and buy sugar, cooking fat, and maize flour

loans.name: Tasleem's Group

texts.en:
Tasleem is the resident of Multan City. She moved there after her marriage. Her home is a small one with three rooms where she lives with her husband and six children. Her husband is 58 years old and has a scrap business in the local market. He works 10-12 hours per day to earn income for his family.  Tasleem’s children could not complete their education and had to start working with their father to financially support the family. Her eldest son has his own business which he started two years ago by receiving his first loan from Asasah. 

Tasleem is a housewife as well as an embroidery artist. She makes beautiful embroidered clothes on order for her neighborhood clients. 
She has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband who wants to expand his scrap business. With the loan, he will buy scrap to sell at his shop. He has five years' experience in this business and he is sure that he can improve his financial condition with the help of an investment. Tasleem is in her third loan cycle. She has proved to be a very responsible loan user and always attends meetings on time.

loans.use: Purchase scrap for scrap business

loans.name: Luganda Kulya Group-Kampala

texts.en: The trend now in Uganda is to do business and get wealthy with time. It is a sharp contrast with the emphasis that was laid on education by most people in the 1970s and 1980s. The situation today favors business undertakings rather than white collar jobs, which are hard to come by. In keeping with this stream of thought, 35-year-old N. Aisha made a decision to start her own tailoring business five years ago. With 100,000 and 400,000 shillings as weekly and monthly profits respectively, she is one happy woman. All of her five children are doing well at school and she is proud of the fact that she is paying their fees. With this loan, Namirima wants to buy more cloth to make more clothes to sell on a large scale. She hopes this will enable her to earn more income.

loans.use: To purchase more clothing materials for her business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: The purchase of more bales of clothes for resale

loans.name: Editha

texts.en:
Editha G. is from the village of Cabisera 25, Ilagan. She is 43 years old and married with four adult children. Editha has a business selling rice in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 4,500 PHP a month.

In 2010, Editha joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI which was used to to purchase additional products to sell and is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will also be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the second loan taken out by Editha from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 21-year-old single man from Lebanon. He lives with his parents and three siblings. Despite his young age, he started his own business in 2007. He decided to purchase a big generator and provide electricity to his town. He chose this business after seeing a need for such services in the region. As do the majority of the Lebanese men, he helps his father with the family expenses. His business was suceeding and he has found an opportunity to expand into other areas. In order to fulfill his project, he needs to buy new tools and supplies. To do so, he is requesting to borrow $1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l.

Note: Based on the political and social challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e., blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, not indicating his/her name and location, etc.) Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Lebanon's borrowers.

About Ameen: Ameen s.a.l. has been a major player in the Lebanese Microfinance sector since 1999. Originally, a micro-credit program created by CHF International, Ameen evolved to become Ameen s.a.l. in 2003, a Lebanese services company. In 2007, Ameen s.a.l. registered with the Central Bank of Lebanon to become the first Lebanese financial institution specialized in Microfinance.

At Ameen s.a.l. we pledge to provide financial services to the largest number of micro and small entrepreneurs and to the working poor, to help them develop their businesses and improve their incomes.

Ameen has been able to use its interest-free loans from Kiva to offer lower-interest loans with faster disbursement for their micro-loan borrowers. Since its inception, Ameen has provided high-quality financial services to over 41,000 borrowers and disbursed over 81,000 loans totaling $115 million. To learn more about Ameen, please visit http://partners.kiva.org/partners/115

loans.use: buy new tools and supplies

loans.name: Gunjuka Okulakulane Group-Mpigi

texts.en: Do good planning and avoid profit loss is the philosophy that has kept 35 year-old W. John’s crafts business on a steady course for the last 20 years. Married, and the father of seven, he makes 60,000 shillings per week. John had to go through an apprentice training mill to learn the trade of making local crafts. Prior to that he was more partial to farming. He also runs a retail business and with the assistance of this loan, he wants to buy more raw materials like sisal and bamboo to make the products he sells. He foresees a scenario where he will be able to make more profit with more crafts made for sale. Since he operates by the side of the road, people can look and admire what he has made.

loans.use: Purchase raw materials like sisal and bamboo to make crafts for sale

loans.name: Majeedan's Group

texts.en: Majeedan lives Multan, an historic city in Pakistan. She has lived in the area of Ghouspura with her husband since she got married. She is the mother of three sons and a daughter. Her children couldn’t complete their education and had to start work in their teens. Her husband has a business making and selling bed-sheets and his three sons assist him in his business. Majeedan is a seamstress and stitches clothes for her neighborhood clients to earn a living for her family. She has applied for a loan for the third time from Asasah for her eldest son. With the loan, he will buy threads in bulk and start his own bed-sheet business because he has acquired enough knowledge and feels that he can run his own business well. In this way they can all earn good profits and change the living standard of their family. Majeedan hopes that she will be able to marry her daughter within a few years by collecting the dowry required from the profits of her family business. She has proved to be a very responsible borrower and always attends meetings on time.

loans.use: Purchase threads to make and sell bed sheets

loans.name: Blessing Development Group-Kampala

texts.en: It is good to know that one can make decisions running their own business, which is what 27-year-old M. Stephern discovered five years ago when he started a secretarial bureau. Prior to that, he was like many other young jobless Ugandans who spend their days looking for jobs. He did secretarial studies as a course at the university. His customers are mostly students around Mpigi Town. In a week, he makes as much as 200,000 shillings and also ekes out more profit from selling crops like maize. Happily married, he has no children yet so his responsibilities are limited. With this loan, he will be able to buy one more computer to make his work easier.

loans.use: The purchase of  a new computer

loans.name: Assibi

texts.fr: D. est une jeune femme de 27 ans, elle a appris la couture et a ouvert son propre atelier. pour augmenter ses sources de revenus, elle a entamée en 2008 le commerce de tissus; ce commerce a été florissant pour elle. sa clientèle se compose de toutes personnes. la demande de tissus est élevée. elle sollicite de WAGES un prêt pour acheter des tissus et satisfaire tous ses clients.
texts.en:
Ms. D. is a young woman who is 27 years old. She learned how to sew and has opened up her own workshop. To increase her sources of revenues, she began a fabrics business in 2008 that has been thriving for her. Her customer base includes anyone. The demand for fabrics is high. She is requesting a loan from WAGES for buying some fabrics and for satisfying all her customers.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying cloth

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase more bananas for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buying jewelry

loans.name: Star Eagle Development-Lugazi Group

texts.en: Three years operating a retail shop is a relatively short period of time, but 30 year old K. Farouk is enjoying every minute of it, given the good profit spells she has been enjoying in that period. This business got off its feet with the assistance of a close friend who talked him out of the idea of only banking on profits from farming. This happy faced married father of 1 makes 100,000 shillings in weekly profits. With this loan, he wants to buy an array of retail items such as sugar and maize flour in bulk to resell in his shop.

loans.use: To purchase an array of retail items such as sugar and maize flour for resale.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace C. is currently in the business of selling earrings, necklaces, and weaving materials in a salon shop, and is requesting a loan to stock more weaving materials to sell. Grace is 31 years old and is married to a husband who is an inspector. She has 2 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to employ an expert to treat customers' hair in the salon shop.

loans.use: To stock more weaving materials to sell.

loans.name: Celina

texts.en:
Celina K. is currently in the business of selling maize, millet, and sorghum at the market, and is requesting a loan to stock maize flour and dried cassava tubers to sell.

Celina is 41 years old and is married to a husband who is a businessman. She has 4 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a store for her cereals.

loans.use: To stock maize flour and dried cassava tubers to sell.

loans.name: Katojo Abamwe, Ibanda Group

texts.en:
Hard working T. Norah is married with 3 children of her own to take care of, and she knows that she has her responsibility tasks cut out for her. This reality has looked her in the face for the past 4 years as she goes about her retail shop business, selling general merchandise, especially for home use, therefore, she is also a teacher in Katojo, Ibanda.

With her monthly earnings amounting to 150,000 Ugandan shillings, she has faced long odds in providing for all her family’s needs and principally catering for her children’s welfare as her husband seems to be negligent. Norah wants to improve on the status quo of her family with the acquisition of this loan, as she wants to give this business an improved lease on life in terms of expansion, through restocking her shop with a vision of making it a wholesale business, and thus earning more sales revenue.

loans.use: To purchase more stock like soap, sugar, salt, cooking oil, books etc. for resale.

loans.name: Enyonam

texts.fr: A. exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de produits cosmétiques, elle fait ce commerce depuis plus de 4 ans et maîtrise le contour de cette activité. elle fait son commerce au marché local d'agoè atsanvé. son stock de marchandises est en baisse. elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour l'achat de 4 cartons de mèches amina, des perruques et divers produits de beauté.
texts.en:
Mrs. A. makes money running a shop selling cosmetic products. She has been running this shop for 4 years and has mastered the complicated aspects of the business. She runs her shop at the local market of Agoè Atsanvé. Her stock of goods is low. She is asking WAGES for a loan to buy 4 boxes of Amina hair extensions, wigs and various other beauty products.

Translated from French by Martha Schmitz, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy hair extensions and beauty products

loans.name: Ludia

texts.en: Ludia Y. is currently in the business of selling maize flour and rice and is requesting a loan to stock bags of beans and pulses (cereals) to sell. Ludia is 42 years old and is married to a businessman. She has 5 children and only 2 of her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to extend the floor of her store.

loans.use: To stock bags of beans and pulses (cereals) to sell.

loans.name: Khairidin

texts.en:
Khairidin A. is a successful father and dedicated husband. He has 4 children, the elder is studying at University and his youngest is still in elementary school. Khairidin began a small grocery store 5 years ago with his savings. He was assisted by his wife, who helps him to serve his clients. Today his clientele has grown greater and his grocery store has become more popular. He is asking for a loan so that he may expand the variety of goods that are sold in his store. Khairidin is very grateful to everyone who is helping him to achieve success in his business with this loan.       

More about Tajikistan and IMON International:

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History:

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase foodstuffs to increase the range of goods for sale.

loans.name: Adjowa

texts.fr: Y. est une femme de 31 ans qui exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce en gros de sel. elle s'approvisionne au ghana voisin. elle a commencé ce commerce en 2009. actuellement elle détient le monopole dans son quartier. elle veut s'approvisionner pour répondre aux commandes de ses clients raison pour laquelle elle sollicite un crédit pour acheter 55 sacs de sel et assurer le transport de la marchandise.
texts.en:
Y. is a 31 year old woman who makes her money running a shop selling coarse salt. She restocks in neighboring Ghana. She started her shop in 2009. Currently she holds the monopoly in her neighborhood. She wants to restock to fill her clients' orders, which is why she is requesting a loan to 55 bags of salt and to ensure her merchandise is transported.

Translated from French by Martha Schmitz, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy salt

loans.name: Beby

texts.en: Beby A. is currently in the business of selling bags of charcoal at the store around the market, and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal to sell. Beby is 49 years old and is widowed. She has 7 children and 3 of her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy a car to transport bags of charcoal from charcoal burners to her store.

loans.use: To stock more bags of charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Izzatulo

texts.en:
Izzatulo K. is a young guy who likes to make his own way. He has run a clothing business for more than 5 years, which is how Izzatulo supports his family. Little by little and with hard work his business has expanded. Still, Izzatulo wants his business to grow even more. For this reason, he is requesting a loan of $1,500 USD that he will spend to buy more merchandise. This way he will have new products to offer to his customers. 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International:

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History:

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase new clothing.

loans.name: Jyldyzkan's Group

texts.en: Jyldyzkan S. is the leader of the group. She is 43 and married. She has raised four sons; the first son works as a dentist and the others are students, except the youngest son. Jyldyzkan and her husband breed cattle and chickens. Seven years ago, with the initial investment of 300 soms (about $6.50), they started to breed chickens. After fattening them, they sold the chickens to Bishkek. That time, Jyldyzkan made good money and since that moment, she has been engaged in the wholesale trade of chickens. She earns 12000 soms (about $257) per month. With the money received from the loan, she wants to purchase hay for cattle and feed for the chickens. In the future, she wants to see her older son get wed, to expand her business and then purchase a vehicle. Sairakan K. is the treasurer of the group. She is 44 and married. She has two daughters and a son. The first daughter works in a barber shop, the second studies at university and the son is at school. In order to make money, Sairakan sells women's clothes in the store. Her husband works as an inspector in the Ministry of Transports. Sairakan has been selling clothes for 15 years; in this way, she makes 12000 soms (about $257) per month. Sairakan applied for the loan because she needs money to pay for her daughter’s education at university. Jamilya A., 52, is married. She has a son and three daughters, all of whom are working. Jamilya and her husband are engaged in cattle breeding and with money received from the loan, they want to purchase barley to feed the cattle during the winter season. Damira J., 44, is married. She has two daughters and a son. The first daughter works as a teacher and the others are students. In order to make money, Damira sells wheat. Her husband works as an operator at the gas station; when he is free, he helps his wife. Damira started with the initial investment of 20000 soms (about $429) and now she makes 4500 soms (about $96) per month. With money received from the loan, she wants to purchase barley in order to resell it later with a higher price. Where Did This Loan Come From? This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple "P" bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase feed for chickens and hay for cattle

loans.name: Gulzamon

texts.en: Gulzamon K. is 50 years old. She is married and has eight children. Gulzamon has been running her own business of selling different kinds of home products for the past 15 years. She sells detergents, hair color, perfume, socks and many other items in her store. The inventory she has for sale is of very good quality and selection. Gulzamon is respectful and patient with all of her customers, which attracts people and brings them back to her vending facility to buy things again. Gulzamon is seeking to keep her business sustainable and has requested a loan of 6000 Somoni to increase the inventory she has for sale. We believe this current loan will enhance the potential of her business and help Gulzamon reach all of her aspirations. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes being a key post along the Silk Road, and for the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.name: Anonymous Group

loans.name: Inobat

texts.en:
V. Inobat is 29 years old, divorced and has one young child. She has run her own business for the last five years, a small store where people buy shampoos, detergents, toothpaste, brushes and other items. Inobat is very friendly and polite, which makes her customers very loyal. She is applying for a loan for $3,000 to buy more goods to sell to her customers. She is committed to repay her loan on time and extends her sincerest thanks to everyone who decides to support her. 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International
Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. A civil war, which ignited soon after independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients have a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy more goods to sell to her customers

loans.name: Musana Kwebisaho, Ntungamo Group

texts.en: K. Mariat, who leads this loan group, is a hard-working and optimistic 52-year-old mother with eight children who range in age from 11 to 25. She operates a  business in the Kyangara Trading Centre, where she buys and sells coffee beans. She has been in this line of work for 20 years, and in that time has managed to significantly improve her family's living standards and pay to educate her children. By all appearances, her business is in good shape, and produces revenues of almost 500,000 Ugandan shillings a month. The prospects for growth also seem strong, which is why she is applying for a loan to buy more items to sell in her shop. By increasing her income, this loan will allow her to continue paying for her children's education, expand her business, and develop a small plot of land she owns into a profitable farm.

loans.use: To expand several small businesses
